div.head: To my LORD of Newcastle, on his PLAY called THE VARIETY. He having commanded to give him my true opinion of it.
div.p: My Lord, I could not think these seven years, but that I In part a Poet was, and so might lie, By the Poetic Licence. But I find Now I am none, and strictly am confined To truth, if therefore I subpoenaed were Before the Court of Chancery to swear. Or if from thence I should be higher sent, And on my life unto a Parliament Of wit and judgment, there to certify What I could say of your VARIETY: I would depose each Scene appeared to me An Act of wit, each Act a Comedy, And all was such, to all that understood, As knowing Johnson, swore by God it was good.

sp.p:
He that could never boast, nor seek the way, To prepare friends to magnify his Play, Nor rail at his Auditory for unjust, If they not liked it nor was so mistrust. Full ever in himself, that he besought Preapprobation though they liked it not. Nor ever had the luck to have his name Clapped up above this merit. Nor the shame To be cried down below it. He this night Your fair and free Attention does invite. Only he prays no prejudice be brought By any that beforehand wish it nought. And that ye all be pleased to hear and see, With Candour suiting his Integrity. That for the Writer. Something we must say, Now in defence of us, and of the Play We shall present no Scandal or Abuse, To virtue or to honour. Nor traduce Person of worth. Nor point at the disgrace Of any one residing in the Place, On which our Scene is laid, nor any Action show, Of thing has there been done, for aught we know.
Though it be probable that such have been. But if some vicious persons be brought in. As no new Buildings, nor the strongest hold Can keep out Rats and Vermin bad and bold. Let not the sight of such be ill endured; All sores are seen and searched before they are cured. As Ruffian, Bawd, and the licentious crew, Too apt to pester Situations new.

It is not amiss ere we begin our Play, To entreat you, that you take the same survey Into your fancy, as our Poet took, Of covent garden, when he wrote his Book. Some ten years since, when it was grown with weeds. Not set, as now it is, with Noble Seeds. Which make the Garden glorious. And much Our Poet craves and hopes you will not grutch It him, that since so happily his Pen Foretold its fair improvement, and that men Of worth and honour should renown the place. The Play may still retain its former grace.

div2.stage: Main text ACT. I. SCENE I. Cockbrayne, Rookes-bill.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Aye marry Sir! This is something like! These appear like Buildings! Here is Architecture expressed indeed! It is a most sightly situation, and fit for Gentry and Nobility.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: When it is all finished, doubtless it will be handsome.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
It will be glorious: and yond magnificent Piece, the Piazzo, will excel that at Venice, by hearsay, (I never travelled). A hearty blessing on their brains, honours, and wealths, that are Projectors, Furtherers, and Performers of such great works. And now I come to you Master. Rookesbill: I like your Row of houses most incomparably. Your money never
shone so on your Counting boards, as in those Structures.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I have piled up a Leash of thousand pounds in walls and windows there.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It will all come again with large increase. And better is your money thus let out on red and white, than upon black and white, I say. You cannot think how I am taken with that Row! How even and straight they are! And so are all indeed. The Surveyor (what ever he was) has manifested himself the Master of his great Art. How he has wedded strength to beauty; state to uniformity; commodiousness with perspicuity! All, all as it should be!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: If all were as well tenanted and inhabited by worthy persons.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Phew; that will follow. What new Plantation was ever peopled with the better sort at first; nay, commonly, the lewdest blades, and naughty packs are either necessitated to them, or else do prove the most forward venturers. Is not lime and hair the first in all your foundations? do we not soil or dung our lands, before we sow or plant anything that is good in them? And do not weeds creep up first in all Gardens? and why not then in this? which never was a Garden until now; and which will be the Garden of Gardens, I foresee it. And for the weeds in it, let me alone for the weeding of them out. And so as my Reverend Ancestor Justice Adam Overdo, was wont to say, In Heavens name and the Kings, and for the good of the Commonwealth I will go about it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p:
I would a few more of the Worshipful hereabouts, (whether they be in Commission or not) were as well minded that way as you are Sir; we should
then have all sweet and clean, and that quickly too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have thought upon a way for it, Master. Rooksbill: and I will pursue it, viz. to find out all the enormities, yet be myself unspied: whereby I will tread out the spark of impiety, whilst it is yet a spark and not a flame; and break the egg of a mischief, whilst it is yet an egg and not a Cockatrice. Then doubt not of worthy tenants for your houses Master. Rooksbill.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, your best furtherance.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I had a letter but last night from a worthy friend, a West country Gentleman, that is, now coming up with his family to live in Town here; and desire is to inhabit in these buildings. He was to lie at Hammersmith last night, and requested an early meeting of me this morning here, to assist him in the taking of a house. It is my business hither; for he could never do it himself. He has the oldest touchy, wrangling humour. --- But in a harmless way; for he hurts nobody, and pleases himself in it. His children have all the trouble of it, that do anger him in obeying him sometimes. You will know him anon. I mean, he shall be your Tenant. And luckily he comes.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It is not enough you tell me of obedience. Or that you are obedient. But I will be obeyed in my own way. Do you see ---

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: My noble friend Master. Croswill, right happily met.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Your troublesome friend Master. Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
No trouble at all, Sir, though I have prevented
yours in finding a fit house for you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You have not have you, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Actum est Master. Croswill. But Civility pardon me, Is not this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: All the She things I have: and would I were well rid of her too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sweet Mistress. Katherine, Welcome --- Master. Gabriel, I take it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel Croswill is my name.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But where is your younger son Mihill? There is a spark!

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: A Spark! A dunce I fear by this time like his brother Sheepshead there.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel is my proper name.

sp.speaker: Gros.
sp.p: I have not seen him this Twelve-month, since I chambered him a Student here in Town.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: In town, and I not know it?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: He knows not yet of my coming neither, nor shall not, till I steal upon him; and if I find him mopish like his brother, I know what I will do.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Have you not heard from him lately?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, often by his letters, less I could read more comfort in them. I fear he is turned Precisian, for all his Epistles end with Amen; and the matter of them is such as if he could teach me to ask him blessing.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: A comfortable hearing of a young man.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Is it so Sir? but I will new mold him if it be so. --- I will tell you Master. Cockbrayne; never was such a father so crossed in his children. They will not obey me in my way. I grant, they do things that other fathers would rejoice at. But I will be obeyed in my own way, do ye see. Here is my eldest son. Mark how he stands, as if he had learned a posture at Knightsbridge
spittle as we came along while ere. He was not only borne without wit, but with an obstinate resolution, never to have any. I mean, such wit as might become a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Was that resolution borne in him think you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It could never grow up in him still as it does else. When I would have him take his horse, and follow the dogs, and associate Gentlemen, in hawking, hunting, or such like exercises, he will run you a foot five mile another way, to meet the brethren of the separation, at such exercises as I never sent him to (I am sure) on workadays. And whereas most Gentlemen run into other men's books, in hands that they care not who reads, he has a book of his own Short writing in his pocket, of such stuff as is fit for no man's reading indeed but his own.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely Sir. ---

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sure you are an Ass. Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You are my father.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What comfort should I have, were my son such.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: And he has nothing but hanged the head, as you see now, ever since Holiday sports were cried up in the Country. And but for that, and to talk with some of the silenced Pastors here in town about it, I should not have drawn him up.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I would I could change a son with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What kind of thing is thy son? ha! dost thou look like one that could have a son fit for me to father, ha? And yet the best take both, and to please you at all adventures, ha?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I am sure there cannot be a worse, or more debauched reprobate than mine is living.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
And is the devil too good a Master for
him, thinkst thou, ha? Wherein can I deserve so ill at thy hands, fellow, whatever thou art, that thou shouldest wish me cumbered with a worse burden, when thou hearest me complain of this, ha? What is this fellow that you dare know him, Friend Cockbrayn? I will not dwell within three parishes of him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My tenant! Bless me from him. I had rather all my Rents were Bawdy houses.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Think nothing of his words, he will forget all instantly. The best natured man living.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Dost thou stand like a son now that hears his father abused, ha?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am praying for the conversion of the young man he speaks of.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Well said, Master. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But by the way, where is your son Anthony? have you not heard of him yet?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Never since he forsook me, on the discontent he took, in that he might not marry your daughter there. And where he lives, or whether he lives or not, I know not. I hope your daughter is a comfort to you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, in keeping her chamber whole weeks together, sullenning upon her Samplery breech-work, when I was in hope she would have made me a Grandfather ere now. But she has a humour, forsooth, since we put your son by her, to make me a match broker, her marriage maker; when I tell you friend, there has been so many untoward matches of Parents making, that I have sworn she shall make her own choice, though it be of one I hate. Make me her matchmaker! Must I obey her, or she me, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I wish, with tears, my son had had her now.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Wherein Sir, (under correction do I disobey you?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: In that very word, under correction, thou disobeyest me. Are you to be under correction at these years? ha! If I have not already taught you manners beyond the help of correction, go, seek a wiser father to mend them.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet give me leave, dear Sir, in my excuse. ---

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Leave out correction then.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: If I were forward as many Maidens are, To wish a husband, must I not be sought? I never was a Gadder: and my Mother, Before she died, adjured me to be none. I hope you will give me leave to keep your house.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: La there again! How subtly she seeks dominion over me! No, housewife, No; you keep no house of mine. I will nestle you no longer under my wing. Are you not fledge; I will have you fly out Aye, as other men's daughters do; and keep a house of your own if you can find it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: We had a kinswoman flew out too lately, I take it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What tellest thou me of her; wiseacres? Can they not fly out a little, but they must turn arrant whores, ha? Tell me of your kinswoman? It is true, she was my Niece; she went to it a little afore her time? some two years since, and so fled from Religion; and is turned Turk, we fear. And what of that in your precisianical wisdom? I have such children as no man has. But (as I was saying,) would ye top me housewife, ha! Look you, now I chide her, she says nothing. Is this obedience, ha?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Perhaps, I might unfortunately cast my affection on a man that would refuse me.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: That man I would desire to know; show me that man; see if I swing him not dares slight my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Still the old humour, self-willed, cross, and touchy; but suddenly reconciled. Come, Master. Croswil, to the business.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: O, you told me of a house you had found for me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes Sir. And here is the Landlord.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Does he look, or go like one could let a house worthy of me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sir, we have able Builders here, that will not carry least show of their buildings on their backs. This is a rich sufficient man, I assure you, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I cry him heartily mercy, and embrace him. And now I note you better, you look like Thrift itself.

div2.stage: Enter Dorcas above upon a Balcony. Gabriel gazes at her. Dorcas is habited like a Courtesan of Venice.

sp.p: I cannot think you will throw away your houses at a cast. You have a son, perhaps, that may, by the commendations you gave of him. Let us see your house.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Come away Master. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Come Sir, what do you gape and shake the head at there? I will lay my life he has spied the little Cross upon the new Church yond, and is at defiance with it. Sirrah, I will make you honour the first syllable of my name. My name is Will. Croswill, and I will have my humour. Let those that talk of me for it, speak their pleasure, I will do mine.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I shall obey you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now you are in the right. You shall indeed. I will make your heart ache else, do ye see.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
But truly I was looking at that Image; that
painted idolatrous image yonder, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O heresy! It is some Lady, or Gentlewoman standing upon her Balcony.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Her Balcony? Where is it? I can spy from her foot to her face, yet I can see no Balcony she has.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What a Knave is this: That is the Balcony she stands on, that which jets out so on the forepart of the house; every house here has one of them.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: It is very good; I like the jetting out of the forepart very well; it is a gallant fashion indeed.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I guess what she is, what ever I have said. O Justice look to thine office.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Come now to this house, and then to my son Mihil, the Spark you spoke of. And if I find him cross too, I will cross him: Let him look to it, Do ye see.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I will see you housed; and then about my project, which is for weeding of this hopeful Garden.

div2.stage:
Ex. omnes.
Gabriel stays last looking up at her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
Why should not we in England use that freedom The famous Courtesans have in Italy: We have the art, and know the Theory To allure and catch the wandering eyes of Lovers; Yea, and their hearts too: but our stricter Laws Forbids the public practise, our desires Are high as theirs; our wills as apt and forward; Our wits as ripe, our beauties more attractive; Or Travellers are shrewd liars. Where is the let? Only in bashful coward custom, that Stoops in the shoulders, and submits the neck To bondage of Authority; to these Laws, That men of feeble age and weaker eyesight Have framed to bar their sons from youthful pleasures. Possets and Caudles on their queasy stomachs,
Whilst I fly out in brave rebellion; And offer, at the least, to break these shackles That holds our legs together: And begin A fashion, which pursued by Cyprian Dames, May persuade Justice to allow our Games. Who knows? I will try. Francisca bring my Lute.

div2.stage:
Enter Fran. with Lute.
While she is tuning her Lute: Enter Nich. Rookesbill, Anthony in a false beard, Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Troth I have a great mind to be one of the Philoblathici, a Brother of the Blade and Baton, as you translate it; now ye have beat it into my head: But I fear I shall never come on and off handsomely. I have metal enough methinks, but I know not how methinks to put it out.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: We will help you out with it, and set it flying for you never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A bots, you mean my money metal, I mean my valour metal I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Peace, hark.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The other flies fast enough already.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Pox on ye peace.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O most melodious.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Most odious, Did you say? It is methinks most odoriferous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What new devise can this be? Look!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She is vanished. Is it not the Mountebanks Wife that was here; and now come again to play some new merry tricks by herself.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A bots on it, I never saw that Mountebank; they say, he brought the first resort into this new plantation, and sowed so much seed of Knavery and Cozenage here, that it is feared it will never out.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay but this creature: What can she be?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And then again, he drew such flocks of idle people to him, that the Players, they say, cursed him abominably.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.p: Thou ever talkest of the wrong matter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Cry mercy Brothers of the Blade and Baton: Do you think if I give my endeavour to it, I shall ever learn to roar and carry it as you do, that have it naturally, as you say.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, as we will beat it into you. But this woman, this musical woman, that set herself out to show so, I would be satisfied in her.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And she be as able as she seems, she has in her to satisfy you, if you were a Brother of ten Blades, and ten Batons.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow --- Peace. I will baton thy teeth into thy tongue else; she bears a stately presence. Thou never sawest her before: Didst thou Toney?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No; but I heard an inkling at the Paris Tavern last night of a she gallant - that had travelled France and Italy; and that she would ---

sp.speaker: (Clot.
sp.p: Baton thy teeth into thy tongue.) write table.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Plant some of her foreign collections, the fruits of her travels, in this Garden here, to try how they would grow or thrive on English earth.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Young Pig was speaking of such a one to me, and that she was a Mumper.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: What is that a Sister of the Scabbard, brother of the Blade?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come, come; we will in, we will in; it is one of our fathers buildings; I will see the Inhabitants. Some money Clot. furnish I say, and quickly. --- I vow ---

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You shall, you shall.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What shall I?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Vow twice before you have it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow, and I vow again, I will coin thy brains. ---

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Hold, hold, take your poll money; I thought I would have my will; and the word I look for, I will coin thy brains. ---

I do not love to give my money for nothing, I have a volume of words here, the worst of them is as good as a blow; and then I save my Crown whole half a dozen times a day, by half a crown a time, there is half in half saved by that.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come let us appear civil, till we have our entrance, and then as occasion serves --- Knock.
Who would you speak withal?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your Mistress, little one.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Do you know her Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No; but I would know her, that is the business: I mean the musical Gentlewoman that was fiddling, and so many in the What do call it even now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What do call her Sir, I pray?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What do call her; it is not come to that yet, prithee let me see and speak with her first.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are disposed I think.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What should we do here else?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You will not thrust in upon a body whether one will or no.

sp.speaker: Ant., Nic.
sp.p: Away you Monkey.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O me, What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O my brave Philoblathici. ---

div2.stage: Ex. omnes. Enter Dorcas, alias Damaris, Madge.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What is the matter the Girl cries out so?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I know not: I fear some rude company, some of the wild crew are broke into the house.

sp.speaker: Fran. Within.
sp.p: Whether would you go, you will not rob the house will ye?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Will ye be quiet Whiskin?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O me it is so: Hell is broke loose; this comes of your new fingle-fangle fashion, your preposterous Italian way forsooth: would I could have kept my old way of pots and pipes, and my Strong water course for customers: The very first twang of your fiddle guts has broke all, and conjured a legion of devils among us.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, there is but a Leash of us. How now? Who have we here? Are these the far travelled Ladies? O thou party purple, or rather parboiled Bawd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Out alas; sure they are devils indeed.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Art thou travelled cross the Seas from the Bankside hither, old Countess of Codpiece row?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Party purple and parboiled Bawd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And is this the Damsel that has been in France and Italy ?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Codpiece row.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Peace ye roaring Scabs: I will be sworn she supped at Paris Tavern last night, and lay not long ago at the Venice by Whitefryers Dock.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Prithee what is she Madge?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A civil Gentlewoman you see she is.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She has none of the best faces: but is she warrantable; I have not had a civil night these three months.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Nor none are like to have here, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O Madge how I do long thy thing to ding diddle ding.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O Nick, I am not in the humour, no more is she to be of the merry pin now; I am sure her case is too lamentable. But if you will all sit down, I will give you a bottle of wine, and we will relate her story to you, so you will be civil.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Well for once, I care not if we be.

div2.stage: A Table bottle, light, and Tobacco stales.

sp.p: Let us set to it then; sit down brother Toney, sit down Gentlewoman, we shall know your name anon, I hope it will fall in your story; sit down Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You will call me brother Clotpoll too when I have taken my oath, and paid my entrance into the fraternity of the Blade and the Baton.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: It is like we shall. Now Lady of the Stygian Lake, thou black infernal Madge, begin the dismal story, whilst I begin the bottle.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: This Gentlewoman whose name is Damyris.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Damyris stay. Her nickname then is Dammy, so we may call her when we grow familiar: and to begin that familiarity, Dammy here is to you. ---

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And what is your nickname I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nick: only Nick, Madge there knows it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Then I believe your name is Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow witty. Yes Dammy, and my Surname is Rookesbill, and so is my Fathers too: and what do you make of that?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Nothing not I Sir: sure this is he.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: And I would he were nothing, so I had all he has: I must have the other glass to wash him out of my mouth, he furs it worse than Mondongas Tobacco. Here old Madge, and to all the birds that shall wonder at thy Owletship, when thou ridest in an Ivy bush, called a Cart.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well mad Nick, I will pledge thee in hope to see as many flutter about the tree, that thou shalt clime backwards.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A pox thou wilt be stifled with Offal and Carrot leaves before that day.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie, fie, what talk is this? it is he I am confident.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: These are our ordinary complements, we wish no harm.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No Dammy I vow, not I to any breathing.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But your Father Nick. --- Is he that Rookesbill. ---

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But my Father; Pox rot ye, why do ye put me in mind of him again, he sticks in my throat, now I will wash him a little further. --- Here Brother Toney

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gramercy Brother Nick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And to all the brothers that are, and are to be of the Blade and the Baton.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: There said you well Clotpoll: Here it is ---

div2.stage: Drink. Mad. sets away the Bottle.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I would but have asked you whether your Father were that Rookesbill that is called the great Builder.

sp.speaker: Nic.
Clot.
sp.p: And to all the Sisters of the Scabbard Brother in Election. Do ye hear, Pray talk of his father no more, for the next brings him to the belly work, and then he will drink him quite through him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And so we shall have a foul house.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No he shall stick there. Now to the story Gentlewoman, it was that we sate for.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Aye to the story, I vow I had almost forgot it; and I am the worst at Sack in a morning: Dear Dammy to the story.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Good Sir my heart is too full to utter it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Troth and my head is too full to hear it: But I will go out and quarrel with somebody to settle my brains, then go down to Mich. Crossewill to put him in mind of our meeting today; then if you will meet me at the Goat at Dinner, we will have it all at large.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Will you be there indeed Sir, I would speak with you seriously.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Dammy if I be not, may my father outlive me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We both here promise you he shall be there by noon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: By'r'Lady, it is sworn by Blade and by Baton.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: This will be the bravest discovery for Mihill, the new Italian Bona Roba Catsoe.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Why so sad on the sudden Niece.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But do you think he will come as he has promised.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: He never breaks a promise with any of us, though he fail all the honest part of the world: But I trust you are not taken with the Ruffian, you will never get penny by him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I prithee peace, I care not.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But Mistress, there is a Gallant now below, a Jingle boy indeed, that has his pockets full of, crowns that chide for vent. Shall I call him up to you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I will see no man.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: How is that? I hope you jest.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Indeed, I hope you jest.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: You will not hinder the house, I hope. Marry heigh. This were a humour if it would last. Go fetch him up.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I will fly then out at window. Nay, by this steel it is true.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What is the matter? have I got a mad woman into the house. What do you go about to break me the first day of your coming, before you have hanselled a Couch or a Bedside in it. Were you but now all of the heigh to set yourself out for a sign with your fiddle cum twang, and promise such wonders, forsooth, and will not now be seen. Pray what is the Riddle.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I will tell thee all anon. Prithee excuse me. I know thy share of his sins bounty would not come to thus much, take it, I give it thee. And prithee let me be honest till I have a mince to be otherwise, and I will hinder thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Well, I will dismiss the Gallant, and send you, Sirrah, for another wench. I will have Bess Bufflehead again. This kicksy, wincy Giddy-brain will spoil all. I will no more Italian tricks. ---

Thus some have by the frenzy of despair Fumously run into the sea to throw Their wretched bodies, but when come near
They saw the billows rise, heard Boreas blow,
And horrid death appearing on the Maine, A sudden fear hath sent them back again.

div2.stage: Act. II. Scaen. I. Enter Mihill. Taylor. Shoemaker.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nay, but honest Shoemaker; thy honest price.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I tell you in truth, Sir, it is as good a boot as ever you pulled on in your life.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A little too straight, I doubt. What do you think of my boots honest Tailor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: They do exceeding handsomely, never trust me Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Never fear it Tailor, you shall trust me, and please you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: You are pleasant Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And what do you think of my suite Shoemaker? can you say as much for the Tailor as he for you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A very neat suite, Sir, and becomes you excellent.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Honest men both, and hold together; one would little think you were so near neighbours. Well, you have fitted me both, I must confess. But how I shall fit you, now there is the point.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: There is but one way for that if please you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: With paying us our money Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Still both in a tale, I cannot but commend your neighbourhood, I muse my Laundress stays,
I sent her three or four ways for moneys. But do not you stay for that. I have ways enough to pay you. I have ploughs a-going that you dream not of.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, we dream of nothing but ready money, sleeping or waking.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I shall be rich enough never fear it. I have a venture in the new soap business man.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: We are but servants, Sir. And our Masters themselves have no faith, in slippery projects.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Besides, the women begin to grumble against that slippery project shrewdly, and, it is feared, will mutiny shortly.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: By'r'Lady, and they may prove more troublesome than a commotion of Sailors.
O welcome, Laundress, where is the money.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Not a penny of money, Sir, can I get. But here is one come to town has brought you enough, if you can have grace to finger it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: who is that I prithee.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Your father, your father, Sir. I met his man by great chance, who told me his Master means to steal upon you presently, and take you as he finds you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Is he come up with his cross tricks. I heard he was to come. And that he means to live here altogether. He has had an aim these dozen years to live in town here, but never was fully bent on it until the Proclamation of restraint spurred him up. It is such a Crossewill. Well, he is my father, and I am utterly undone if thou helpest me not now at a pinch, at a pinch, dear Laundress. Go borrow me a Gown,
and some four or five Law books? for, I protest, mine are in Duck lane. Nay, trudge, sweet Laundress, trudge. ---
Honest Tailor and Shoemaker convey yourselves away quietly, and I will pay you tomorrow, as I am a Gentleman:

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: As I am a Shoemaker, and that is a kind of a Gentleman, you know, I will not stir till I have my money, I am not an Ass Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nobody says thou art.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: I have had too many such tricks put upon me in my days.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A trick! as I hope for money it is no trick.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Well Sir, trick or no trick. I must have my money or my boots, and that is plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A pox on the boots, so my legs were out of them. Would they were in thy throat, spurs and all, you will not out.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: No marry will we not.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Well said Shoemaker, I commend thee, thou hast a better heart than I, though my stomach is good.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: O well said, my good Laundress. How am I bound to thee; yet all this will not do it Laundress. Thou must bestir thy stumps a little further, and borrow me a couple of Gowns more for these Rascals here that will not away.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: How I would not away? And they were well served, they would be thrust out of doors for saucy companions. Your Masters would not put a Gentleman to his trumps thus.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Nay, sweet Laundress, restrain thy tongue, and stretch thy feet. A couple of Gowns, good
Laundress, and forget not caps.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: If you do, Sir, I may hap be even with you before the year comes about, and set you in our stocks for it.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: But will you make Lawyers of us.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you a mind to have your money you unbelieving Rascals.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: I see your drift, and hope you will prove an honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou hast some hope, though no faith nor trust in any man.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, our Masters sit at great rents, and keep great families.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, they are removed into the new plantation here, where, they say, are a tribe of Infidel tradesmen, that have made a Law within yourselves to put no trust in Gentlemen. But bear yourselves handsomely here you were best. I am acquainted with a crew that haunts about your habitations, with whom I will join, and so batter your windows one of these nights else. --- O welcome, Laundress, how dost thou toil for me.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p:
Your fathers talking, as I am a woman, below.
--- As thou art a woman below, well said. Come on with these Gowns, and let us see how you will look. If we had time, the Shoemaker should wash his face; but seeing there is no remedy; pull the cap in your eyes, and good enough. Now Laundress, set us stools, and leave us.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: I hear him coming up.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Now let him come, we are ready for him. Shoemaker, keep your hand underneath the
book, that the pitch do not discover you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And Taylor, be sure you have no Needle on your sleeve, nor thread about your neck.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I warrant you too for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.p: He is enured.

div2.stage: Enter Croswill, Belt, and stand aside.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Remitter, I say, is where a man hath two titles, that is to say, one of an elder, the other of a later. And he cometh to the land by the later title; yet the Law adjudgeth him to be in by the force of the elder title. If the tenant in the tail discontinue the tail, and after he diseaseth his discontinue, and so dieth seized, whereby the tenants descend to their issue, as to his Cousin inheritable by force of the tail. In this case the tenants descend, who have right by force of the tail, a Remitter in the tail taken for that in the Law, shall put and adjudge him to be in by force of descent. Pox on ye, speak something good or bad, somewhat.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The Remitter, you say, is seized in the tail.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Excellent Shoemaker, I say so, and again, I say, that if the tenant in the tail in feoff his son, or his Cousin, inheritable by force of the tail, the which son or cousin at the time of the feoffment is within age, and after the tenant in the tail dierh, this is a Remitter to the heir in the tail, to whom the feoffment is made, now Taylor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Think you so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Look either Fitzherbert, Perkins, or Dier, and you shall find it in the second part of Richard, Cordelyon. So much for Remitter. Now I will put a plain homespun case, as a man may say, which we call a moot case.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I pray do Sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Some father might take joy of such a son now. This takes not me. No, this is not my way.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: The case is this (aside) pull up your grounds close and behanged, you are a Tailor, and you: a Shoemaker.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And you owe us money.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I put the case, I do, to you for a suit of clothes.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And to you for a pair of boots.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have broke my day, with you both. Suppose so.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Very well, we do.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You clap a Sergeant on my back. I put in bail, remove it, and carry it up into the upper Court, with habeas Corpus; bring it down again into the lower Court with procedendo; then take it from thence, and bring it into the Chancery with a Certiorari; Aye; and if you look not, to it, bring it out of the Chancery again, and thus will I keep you from your money till your suite and your boots be worn out before you recover penny of me.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: 'Slid but you shall not, your father shall know all first.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'sfoot Shoemaker wilt thou be an Ass. I do but put a case, Have you not seen it tried.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Yes, very often.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p:
Away with books. Away with Law. Away with madness. Aye, God bless thee, and make thee his servant, and defend thee from Law, I say. Take up these books, sirrah, and carry them presently into Pauls Churchyard do ye see, and change them all for Histories, as pleasant as profitable; Arthur of Britain,
Primalion of Greece, Amadis of Gaul, and such like do ye see.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope he does but jest.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: And do you hear, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Aye Sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Get Bells work, and you can, into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Which Bell, Sir? Adam Bell, with Clim of the Clough, and William of Cloudesley.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Adam Bell you Ass? Valiant Bell that killed the Dragon.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You mean Saint. George.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sir Jolthead, do I not. I will teach you to chop logic, with me.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'sfoot, how shall I answer my borrowed books? Stay Belt. Pray Sir, do not change my books.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, I will change them and you too: Did I leave thee here to learn fashions and manners, that thou mightst carry thyself like a Gentleman, and dost thou waste thy brains in learning a language that I understand not a word of? ha! I had been as good have brought thee up among the wild Irish.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Why alas Sir, Had I not better keep myself within my Chamber, at my Study, than be rioting abroad, wasting both money and time, which is more precious than money? if you did know the inconvenience of company, you would rather encourage and commend my retired life, than any ways dehort me from it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why Sir did not I keep company think you when I was young? Ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes Sir; but the times are much altered, and youth more corrupted now, they did not drink and wench in those days, but nay, o it is abominable in these.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Why this is that I feared, the boys turning
meacock too, after his elder brother, it was time to look to him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why Croswill Mich. What, not up yet and behanged. Or have ye a wench a bed with ye. Is this keeping your home.

div2.stage: Mihil runs to the door and holds it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'sfoot the Rogue Rooksbil and his crew, I feared as much.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Break open the door, let me come to it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Forbear, or behanged, you will undo me, my father is here. I will meet you anon as I am honest.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your father is a Clowterdepouch. Nay, I will come then, what Madamoiselle do you call father.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You would not believe me. Pray be civil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is so, we will Cry mercy, you are busy, we will not moot today then?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope you may excuse me, I will be with ye anon.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come to the Goat Capricorn. We have the bravest new discovery.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: How now! what are these?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: They are Gentlemen of my standing, Sir, that have a little overstudied themselves, and are somewhat --- .

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Mad; are they not? And so will you be shortly, if you follow these courses. Mooting do they call it? you shall moot nor mute here no longer. Therefore on with your cloak and sword, follow me to the Tavern and leave me such long-tailed company as these are, for I do not like them.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No more do I, Sir, if I knew how to be rid of them.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I think thou hast never a sword, hast thou, ha?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Where is it, Sir, let me see it Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It is here, under my bed, Sir. --- Reach it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why there is a Lawyers trick right, make his weapon companion with his Piss-pot. Fie, fie, here is a tool indeed. There is money, Sir, buy you a good one, one with the Mathematical hilt as they term it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It would do better in Mathematical books Sir, offer me no money, pray Sir, but for books.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Go to, you are a peevish Jack, do not provoke me: do not you owe me obedience? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It is good you do. Well, take that money; and put your self into clothes befitting your rank, Do so. And let me see you, squirting about without a weapon, like an Attorneys Clerk in Term time, and I will weapon you. What, shall I have a Noddy of you. This frets him to the liver. Go to, never hang the head for the matter. For I tell thee I will have it so, and herein be known what I am.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are known sufficiently for your cross humour already; in which I will try you if I can make you double this money, for this will not serve my turn.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What have you told it after me, you had best weigh it too.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No Sir, but I have computed that for my present use; here is too much by half, pray Sir, take half back.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Body of me, what a perverse knave is this, to cross me thus! Is there too much, say you? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes truly, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Let me see it. Go thy ways, take thy musty books, and thy rusty whirl here again. And take your foolish plodding dunce-cox comely course, till I look after you again. Come away sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'sfoot, who is the Gull now? Taylor, Shoemaker, you may go pawn your Gowns for any money I am like to have.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: We have all played the Lawyers to pretty purpose, in pleading all this while for nothing. Well sir, to avoid further trouble, I am content to withdraw my action, that is, pull off your boots again, and be jogging.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And for my part, sir, I can do no less then take you by default and non-suit you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Very good Lawyers both, Is my father quite gone Belt?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Gone in a tempest of high displeasure, sir: And has sent you here: all the money he had about him; and bids you refuse it if you dare, it is above twice the sum he offered you before; but good sir, do not refuse it. He swears he will try whether you or he shall have his will. Take heed you, cross him not too much.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well at thy request, because thou shalt not have anger for carrying it back again, I will accept.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank you Sir. Consider, he is your father, sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
I do most Reverend Belt. and would be loath to cross him, although I may as much in taking his money as refusing it, for aught I know, for thou knowest it is his custom to cross me, and the rest
of his children in all we do, to try and urge his obedience; it is an odd way: therefore to help myself I seem to cover the things that I hate, and he pulls them from me; and makes show of loathing the things I covet, and he hurls them doubly at me, as now in this money.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Are you so crafty?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes, but do thou put it in his head, and I will pick out thy brains.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You never knew an old Serving-man treacherous to his young Master: what? to the hopes of the house; you will be heir, that is questionless: for to your comfort, your elder brother grows every day more fool than the other. But now the rest of the message is, that you make haste, and come to my Master to the Goat in covent garden, where he dines with his new Landlord today.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He has taken a house then.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O, a most delicate one, with a curious Balcony and all belonging to it most stately.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: At the Goat does he dine, sayst thou.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My crew are gone thither too. Pray Mars we fall not foul of one another. Well, go thy way, present my duty to him, I will follow presently. Tell him I took his money with much unwillingness.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: As Lawyers do their fees. Let me alone sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well Tailor and Shoemaker; you have put me to it, but here is your money.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: It was for that we did put you to it Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Let us see your bill Tailor

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: Here it is, sir, as ready as a Watchman's.

sp.speaker: Mi.
Shoo.
sp.p: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Are you right Tailor.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: Yes and please your Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There is a shilling for you too, to spend in bread.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: He knows both our diets. We will make bold to take leave of your worship.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Not so bold as I am glad I am too well rid of you, most courteous Gentlemen.

To see what money can do; that can change men's manners, alter their conditions: how tempestuous the slaves were without it. O thou powerful metal! what authority is in thee! Thou art the Key to all men's mouths. With thee a man may lock up the jaws of an informer, and without thee he cannot the lips of a Lawyer.

div2.stage: Scoen. II. Enter Crossewill, Rookesbill, Gabriel, Katherine, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Down boy, and bid the Cook hasten dinner.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: What will you please to drink in the mean time, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I will not drink in the mean time, sir, Get you gone.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: A fine old humorous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Hold up your head, Sirrah, and leave your precise folly. I will leave yon to the wild world else, do ye see. Is the name of a Tavern so odious to you? Ha. Your brother has vexed me sufficiently already, and perhaps he will refuse to come too! If he dares let him. Welcome Master. Rooksbil, welcome Landlord, and your fair daughter, welcome pretty one. Trust
me a pretty one indeed, pray be acquainted with my daughter there. In your Maiden company, I hope she will not think the Tavern such a bugs nest as she did. I had much ado to draw my rebellious children to the Tavern after me.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And truly, sir, it is the first to my knowledge that ever my daughter came into.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: All in good time, she may increase in virtue. But if it be a fault, (as is my conscience in his thought it is a great transgression) my unsettledness, and unprovidedness else, where or how to entertain a friend, or feed myself, may well excuse us all, do ye see.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O Sir, I cannot enough admire that virtue in your son.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It is a vice, as much a vice or more, as is your sons, your castaways as you call him, that sucks no other air, than that of Taverns, Tap-houses, Brothels, and such like. I would their extreme qualities could meet each other at halfway, and so mingle their superfluities of humour unto a mean betwixt them. It might render them both allowable subjects, where now the one is a fire-drake in the air, and the other a mandrake in the earth, both mischievous, see how he stands like a mole catcher. What dirty dogged humour was I in when I got him trow?

sp.speaker: Rookes.
sp.p: However his carriage seems distasteful unto you, I could afford (with your allowance, to make conditions of estate agreeable) to give all that is mine to him with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
What a mechanic slave is this, to thank a son of mine, However I underrate him, a fit mate to mingle blood with his moor ditch breed. True, his estate is great, I understand it, but of all soul I love not Moorhens. Such another motion
would stir me to roar him down the tavern stairs.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: What do you think on it sirs.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Heaven grant me patience.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Will you consider of it Master Crossewill.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I was never so put to it. I wish we had a stickler. I muse that Master Cockbrayne stays thus.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: You do not mind my motion sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Gods precious I mind nothing, I am so crossed in mind that I can mind nothing, nor I will mind nothing, do ye see. Why comes not Master. Cockbrayne, Ha!

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Yet you mind him it seems. But he, sir, cannot come, and desires you to hold him excused. He is gone about some special undertaking, for the good of the Commonwealth, he says.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Fart for his undertaking; all the world is bent to cross me. What is my young Master come? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: My young Master Master. Mihil will be here presently, he said he would follow me at heels, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: And why not come before you, sir. Does he not think that I have waited long enough, sir? sure I will cross somebody under that knaves pate of yours, do ye see.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Thus when anybody angers him, I am sure to hear of it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: So now my spleen is a little palliated, let me speak with you Master. Rooksbill. Get you down, Sirrah, and bring me word, dinner is not ready, and I will give you as much more, do ye see.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: that is his way to his stomach.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And is your brother that your father says is so ungracious, so well acquainted with my brother Mihil, say you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O all in all, he is not so familiar with any man, if Mihil Croswill be your brother, as it is manifest.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I would not that my father knew it, for all I can expect from him but his blessing, but does your father know it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, I would not he should mistrust it for all he has, blessing and all; and now that I have found you love your brother so well, I will make over my reason and my counsel in trust with you, hoping you will not wrong that trust.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: If I do, may the due price of treachery be my reward.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I love your brother, Lady, and he loves me. The only good act that ever my brother did, was to bring us acquainted, and is indeed all that he has to live on. For I do succour him with many a stolen piece for the felicity he brought me in your brothers love. Now, my father, whose irreconcilable hate has for ever discarded my brother, should he but dream of their acquaintance, would poison all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But let me ask you, is there an hope betwixt you and my brother ever to come together?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, and a way he has for it, which I understand not yet.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Trust me, I pity you both, your case is very dangerous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Love is above all adventures, the more hard the achievement is, the sweeter the reward.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I like her spirit well.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
You Sir, come hither, what is hammering in your head now?
Is it not some Synodical question to put unto the brethren, concerning Whitsonales and May-games? ha!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely sir, I was premeditating a fit thanksgiving to be rendered before meat in Taverns, according to the present occasion which the time and place administereth, and that as the spirit shall enable me, shall be delivered before you in due season.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I am glad I know your mind; for that trick, my zealous son, you shall come in at half dinner, like a Chafing-dish of coals, when the sauce is cold, to make use of the heat of your spirit; do ye see. I love not meat twice dressed.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good sir, put the Proposition to him, that I made my affection to him, urges it more and more, I never was so taken with a man.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But what is that to your daughter? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: The same affection governs her, she is not mine else.

sp.speaker: Cros
sp.p: Well, hold your peace, and was that your spiritual meditation?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, verily.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Come Sir, at this Gentleman's request I will now put a question to you concerning the flesh. What think you of yond Virgin there, his daughter? can you affect her so well as to wish her to be your wedded wife?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You mean, espoused in holy Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, I mean so.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: hum hum hum Psalm tune. How happy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But do thou say, yes verily to that, and as I hope to have peace in my grave. I will break the Kings peace on thy pate presently.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is a weighty question, and requires due premeditation in a religious answer, pray give me leave to take advice ---

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What says he, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: He says he will talk with a cunning man about her.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Sure you mistake him, sir.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: You are welcome, Gentlemen. Will. Harry, Zachary.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Zachary is a good name.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Where are you? he
show up into the Phoenix. Is the Check empty?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Heyday, here is a din.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: A pottle of Canary to the Dolphin, score.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: You are welcome, Gentlemen, take up the lily-pot.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Half a dozen of clean pipes and a candle for the Elephant. They take their own Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Vint,
sp.p: Whose room do they foul Sirrah, Harry, Harry?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do Elephants take Tobacco?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Carry up a Jordan for the Maidenhead, and a quart of white muscadine for the blew Bore.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now methinks, the muscadine for that Maidenhead, and the Jordan for the Bore were better.
Knock above, and a pot thrown. Why boys, drawer, rogues, take up,
By and by, by and by,
Wine, Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What variety of noises is here? and all excellent ill sounds.
Call up the Fiddlers, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such cries as these went forth before the desolation of the great City.
O profane tinkling the cymbals of Satan, that tickle the ear with vanity, to lift up the mind to lewdness. Mine ears shall be that of the Adder against the Song of the Serpent.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O rare, in a young man!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will roar out aloud to drown your Incantations. Yea, I will set out a throat even as the beast that belloweth.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Most happy youth!

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Hold your peace, Sirrah, or I will make you bellow for something.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'Sfoot back, Nick to your own room. Thy father is here too, as I breath.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My Lucie too, as I live. How the devil got they acquainted? Sure he is his Landlord. It is so.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Dare you come sir, you should have stayed now till you had been sent for.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Verily, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Are you at your Verilies too? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: But for displeasing you, I had rather have grazed on Littletons Commons, or have fasted this fortnight, then come for my repast into this Wilderness; but you will have it so.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You are in the right Sir, I will have it so indeed, I will know why I shall not else. What do you know nobody here?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I cry them mercy, my good brother, --- and my loving sister.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: But what virtuous men has this man to his sons, and how they thrive in grace against his will, it seems.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: What Gentlewoman is this of your acquaintance, Sister?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It is well dissembled brother, but I know your cunning.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you betrayed me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mum Master. Mihil, mum.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Harry, Harry.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: By and by.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What devil art thou that roarest in mine care so.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Hold, I beseech you, I come to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What, with a By and by, that strikes into my head as sharp as a Stiletto.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I come to tell you, sir, that your table is covered in a fairer Room, and more private, your meat is ready to go up, and all in a readiness.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now thou art an honest fellow, there is a couple of shillings for thee. Have us out of thy windmill here, I prithee, and thy By and bys.

div2.stage: Act. III. Scoen I. Enter Captain Driblow, Clotpoll, Nick, Anthony, Drawer, A Table, Pot and Glasses.

sp.p: Go Sirrah, make your reckoning for our dinner. Leave us this wine, and come when we call you. We have business.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I shall, sir, by and by.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, sir, you will be of both you say, the Blade and the Baton?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Of both, sir, by all means, both Philoblathicus and Philobatticus, I. I will now have all that belongs to your order, or all my money again, that is for a certain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your money again? lo you there. You bring me a fit man, Gentlemen to be sworn, do you not? that talks of money again, when it is a main Article in the Oath, never to look for money again, once disfingered.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You will not spoil all now it is come so far will you?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Well sir, when I have my Oath, and that I am sworn one of you. I will do as you do, and care as little for money as he that has least.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, to the Oath then, for both the Blade and the Baton you say?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Aye by all means, Captain, for both. 'slid the Baton may stick to me, when the Blade may fly out of the Hilts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, to the Brokers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Lay your hands on these Hilts, sir. The Articles that you depose unto are these, To be true and faithful unto the whole Fraternity of the Blade and the Baton, and to every member thereof.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: As ever faithful member was.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That at no time, wittingly or ignorantly, drunk or sober, you reveal or make discovery of the Brother, or a member of the Brotherhood, of his lodging, haunts, or by-walks, to any Creditor, Officer, Sutler, or such like dangerous or suspicious person.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I defy them all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That if any of the Brotherhood be in restraint or distress by imprisonment, sickness, or whatsoever engagement, you make his case your own, and your purse and your travel his; and that if a brother die or finish his days, by end timely or untimely, by Surfeit, Sword, or Law. You wear the sable order of the Riband in remembrance of him.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A convenient cheap way of mourning.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
That your purse and weapon to the utmost
of your strength, be on all occasions drawn to the assistance or defence of a Brother or Brothers friend, be it he, be it she.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I understand you, and shall be as forward to fight for a She friend, as ever the best man in the mirror of Knighthood was for an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That you be ever at deadly defiance with all such people, as Protections are directed to in Parliament, and that you watch all occasions to prevent or rescue Gentlemen from the gripes of the Law brissons. That you may thereby endear yourself into noble society, and drink the juice of the Varlets labours for your officious intrusions.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And that will go down bravely.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You must rank yourself so much the better man, by how much the more drink you are able to purchase at others costs.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You are to let no man take wall of you, but such as you suppose will either beat you or lend you money.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Better and better still.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The rest of your duties for brevity sake you shall find specified in that copy of your Order. Kiss the book.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I will swear to them whatsoever they be. So, now I am a Blade, and of a better Row than those of Tytere tu, or Carmeal hoe, and so an health to our Fraternity, and in chief to our Noble Captain Driblow.

sp.speaker: Nick., Ant.
sp.p: Agreed, Agreed.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now are you to practise or exercise your quality on the next you meet that is not of the Brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Are you one of the Brotherhood sir, of the Philoblathici.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I had else lost much sir, I have paid all dues belonging to it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So have I as I hope to gain honour by it 40 li. thick at least; yet I have this left, please you command the half sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Another time, your reckoning is not yet paid perhaps.

div2.stage: [Clot. puts his money in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: It is the first money of mine that was refused since my coming to Town. I shall save infinitely. I see now that I am sworn. How would I swear to get by it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Take heed of that, Come hither son.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: How have you screwed this youth up into this humour, that was such a dry miserable Clown but two days since.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The old way, by watching of him, and keeping him high-flown a matter of forty eight hours together.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Men are apt to believe strange fancies in their liquor, and to entertain new opinions.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have fastened three or four cups upon my precise brother. I would it were as many pottles, so it would convert him into the right way of good fellowship.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I would we could see him, to try what good we could do upon him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Perhaps we might convert him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He is above still with the old men. I stole from him, but to see if your Italic Mistress were come yet. Your Madam.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, she comes anon; but is my affliction above still.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thy father? yes

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Prithee do not call him my father less he took better courses.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And so is thy Sister; the little Rogue looks so squeamishly on me, and I on her, as we had never seen before; but the foolish Ape out of a present affection she has taken to my Sister, has discovered to her the whole discourse of our love, and my familiarity with thee, which were enough to spoil all, if it were discovered to the old folks, before my cards were played.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, remember Master. Mihil, you have promised me half, if the old dogged fellow give her all, and you marry her.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou canst not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Nick
sp.p: You know I can spoil all when I lift, but to show my countenance in your cause.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Such is your virtue, Sir. Well, I will up to them again before I be missed; and when they part, I am for you again.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have given you all the rudiments, and my most fatherly advices withal.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the last is that I should not swear, how make you that good? I thought now I was sworn into this Brotherhood, I might have sworn what, and as much as I would.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That is most unnecessary, for look you son, the best, and even the lewdest of my sons do forbear it, not out of conscience, but for very good ends; and in stead of an Oath furnish the mouth with some affected Protestation. As I am honest, it is so. I am no honest man if it be not. God take me, if I lie to you. Never go, never stir, I vow, and such like.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or never credit me. or let me never be trusted.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: O take heed of that, that may be spoken in so ill an hour, that you may run out of reputation, and never be trusted indeed; the other will gain you credit, and bring you into good and civil estimation with your Hostesses; and make them term you a fair conditioned Gentleman if he had it; and truly I never heard worse word come out of his mouth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Never go, never stir, I vow. I will have, I vow then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow, but you shall not, that is mine.

sp.speaker: Clot
sp.p: Cannot you lend it me now and then brother? I will have, I swear then, and come as nigh swearing as I can.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I swear but you must not, that is mine you know.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest then, I will have I protest, that is a City word, and best to cozen with.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Come boys, fall to some practice, Let me see about at the new French balls, sprung out of the old English vapours

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest come on. I will make a third man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whose man are you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Whose man is not to be asked, nor scarce whose subject, now he is of our Brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, by your favour he may ask.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ask no favour, sir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: That may be granted.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You can grant nothing in this kind.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow he may grant anything of any kind.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I swear, I neither can, nor will grant that.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: That, I protest, may bear exception indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Exceptions amongst us? nay, then I vow. ---

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I swear.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I protest ---

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Part fair my boys; it is very well performed; now drink a round to qualify this bout.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed on all parts.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Look upon me ye Commonwealths men now, like a state surgeon, while I search and try The ulcerous core of foul enormity. These are a parcel of those venomous weeds, That rankly pester this fair Garden plot. Whose boisterous growth is such, that I must use More policy than strength to reach their root, And hoist them up at once. This is my way to get within them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, it is gone round.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I muse these Mumpers come not.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Best send a boy.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Drawer, ha! where be those Rascals?
By and by.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are you one of them, sir?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I am one that has the favour of the house, sir?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To intrude into Gentlemen's privacies? ha!

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: To seek a poor living if it please you, by picking up the crumbs of your liberality, for the use of my rare qualities.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And what is your quality?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It is to speak or sing ex tempore upon any Theme, that your fancy or the present occasion shall administer.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can you drink before you lay your lips to it

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O my weak eyesight.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or can you eat a crust without chewing, made of the Flower of Baton.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good Gentlemen, forbear, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The flower of Baton. I protest a good jest, and it was mine own before I was aware, for he had the Maidenhead or first blow of my Baton. Nay, it shall down.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I will not yet desist; but suffer private affliction with a Roman resolution for the public welfare, with full assurance that my fortitude shall at last get within them.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You are not satisfied, it seems, you Rascal, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Phew! beat not the poor fellow so:

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Let me come to him again, and flesh myself upon him. I will not only flesh myself, but tire upon him.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Enough, enough, good Gentlemen, you have beaten me enough of conscience. Was ever good Patriot so rudely handled? but the end crowns all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Forbear him sons. What canst thou be, that canst not be satisfied with beating? speak, art a man or a Ghost?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have been, Sir, a man, and of my hands, however misfortune humbles me under your manhoods. But I have seen the face of war, and served in the Low countries, though I say it, on both sides.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Then it is impossible this fellow can be beat out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Mick.
sp.p: We will leave him in his quality for that constant virtue.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sure, it is Fenner or his Ghost. He was a riming soldier. Look, do his eyes stand right?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: They had a dish even now, sir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Of sack, it is true here, take another, and wash the inside of your Throat. And let us hear your pipes in their right tune.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Give me a Theme Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The praise of sack. Sing the praise of sack.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let it be of the Blade.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the Baton, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Do you call, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I will have sack.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The other quart of Canary? you shall.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are your ears so quick? I vow, I will dull them.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I say, a song of Sack.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Aye, let it be of Sack.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Now you pump, do you?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No, sir, but think of a tune.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: If he can pump us up a spring of Sack, we will keep him, and break half the Vintners in Town.

div2.stage: ( Song. Now B. and Clot. asks Gabriel, Are you a brother. They fall in the burthen.)

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, well said.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I swear, it was well.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest the best that I have heard in this kind. I wonder at his ability. I prithee, art not acquainted with my two Poetical Drury-lane Writers? the Cobbler and the Tapster.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No sir, not I, I work not their way. What I do is ex tempore after the Theme given.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But they run quite before you. Their Works are in print sometimes. and ready to be sung about streets, of men that are hanged before they come to the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But did not Mihil say he would come again.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I marvel at his stay.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Aye, and the Mumpers, when come they? I long to see the Sisters, now I am a brother sworn and entered.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O here comes news. How now pig?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: You must all presently to the Paris Tavern.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Must? at whose suit!

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Master. Mihil bade me tell you so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is he gone from hence?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: He is, and all his gone and dispersed.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Then the old Jew my father is gone.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Only there is one delicate demure Gentleman with Master. Mihil. travelled along with him towards Paris. I believe he means to make a mouth of him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, it is his precise brother. But where is thy Mistress, and Madama Damaris? that they come not.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: They desire to meet you there too, it is more private.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Away we will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Pig, how does thy father Hog, the Turkey Merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: I am in haste, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why Turkey Merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Because he trades in nothing but Turkey commodities; Eggs and Concubines; it were well to geld him, and send him to the Grand Seignior, to wait in his Seraglio.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Thou hast such a wit in this Clotpoll of thine. The Reckoning Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here, here, Sir, here is your bill.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let see the sum. What is it Drawer?
40. shillings. and 3. pence. Sir, your dinner, and what you had since, in all, sir.

sp.speaker: Capt,
sp.p: It is very reasonable, Commend me to thy Master. Son Clotpoll pay it. It is your duty.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, for my Brothership.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Boys, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: 40. shillings. for four men's dinners, note that, yet he says it is reasonable.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Good Captain, He was ever the fairest Reckoner, though he has never the luck to pay anything.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fare you well, father.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: When we have further occasion, we will repair to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: At Bloomsbury. Father, I know.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Bloomsbury? good, I note it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sirrah, look to the second Article of your Oath.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Against discovery of lodgings, haunts, or by-walks, I am warned.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Look that you be so.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 40. shillings. and 3. pence. you will bate the 3. pence. will you not?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: We will not much stand for that Sir, though our Master sits at dear rent.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Give me your two pieces.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray let me see the bill before you pay it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, I can hold it then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bread and beer, 1. shillings. 4. pence. I do not think we four could eat 3. pence. of bread, and for my part, I drank but two glasses of beer.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And I but one, I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And my father and I but one betwixt us, I protest.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Have you no men below?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Below the earth doest mean? I am sure we have none above-ground.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I know not, Gentlemen, there is so much reckoned at the bar, if you please you may see it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, if it be at the bar, it stands for Law. Well, wine 5 shillings. 9. pence. I think we had no less. A Shoulder of Mutton stuffed with Oysters 8. shillings. that cost your Master very near ten groats, a brace of Partridge 5. shillings. a couple of Cocks 4. shillings. 6. pence. a dozen of Larks 20. pence. Anchovies 6. shillings. I swear but a Saucer full.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I will be sworn they are so much reckoned in the Kitchen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All is law, I tell you, all is law in Taverns. But I hope there will be a law for you one of these days. Then is their Fruit and Cheese, Tobacco, Fire, and I know not what, is it right cast.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: There is more hope of that young man, than of all the rest, indeed it is a sore abuse, another very weed in the city. I do note that also.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sirrah, before you have your money, fetch me a glass of Beer. But canst thou sing this upon any subject.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Any sir, any, if it be till midnight.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But you have strange helps to your invention. I did note the rolling of the eye, and rubbing your Brows sometimes.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So did I, I protest, and therefore, I tell you what. If he can sing such another Song, and look steadfastly the while upon anything, and hold his hands behind him. I will give him half a crown; if not, he shall have nothing for the other.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Agreed Gentlemen, give me your Theme.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You shall give it him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And withal, watch him if he stir hand or eye, especially the eye.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I will I protest, and set mine eye against his, that he shall not twink, but I will perceive it, and lay him over the pate.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Well Sir, your Theme.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: In praise of the Baton, and if you miss it you shall be sure of it.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: You will help me with the burthen, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, yes, for the more grace of the Song.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take you no care for that. Set your eyes and begin.

To prove the Baton the most noble to be.
Of all other weapons observe his degree, In Field to be Leader of all other Arms, To conquest and honour, through hazard and harms. The Gallant and Peasant, the Lord and the Lown. Must move by the motion of the Leaders Baton. O give me the Baton. The Pike and the Halberd are subject to it. The Ensign, the Partisan, all must submit, To advance, or retire, fall back, or come on. As they are directed by the Leaders Baton. Then it is to the Soldier the greatest Renown, To purchase by service to bear the Baton. O give me the Baton.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Marry, and take it Sir, why do you stare about? though you have broke Covenant, I have not.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Where be the Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Ha! they are not gone, I hope, where be my brothers Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Gone sir, and have sent me to you for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest you jest, do you not? I gave them the full sum, and all the money I had, I protest, I swear, I vow, now they are not here, I may make bold with their words. They have my money, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: If you have no money, pray leave a pawn, sir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take him there, put him in a cage, and let him sing it out.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: We know him not, sir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: No? he said he had the favour of the house to sing to Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I fear I shall be discovered, sir, I can give your worship credit for a piece till you come to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Protest, thou art generous; nay, I know where to find them; and thou shalt go with me to them, we will not part now, we will shun them. I vow, (the words out) here, I will leave my sword for the other piece.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Your sword will not serve sir, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take my coat too, a friend and a Baton is better than a coat and a sword at all times.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I am glad my fear is over. And after all my sufferings, if at last Cockbraine crow not these roaring Lions down, Let him be balladed about the Town.

sp.speaker: Luc.
