sp.p: Let me now bid you welcome to my fathers house, where till your own be fitted, though my father keep too private a family to express large entertainment, yet I hope at worst you shall have convenient lodging.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Indeed, I am glad that my father yielded to your fathers friendly request in it; and the more in regard he is so hard to be entreated to anything; but especially for your societies sake, sweet Sister. Indeed I will call you Sister always, and I hope you shall be shortly in my brother Mihils right.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have laid open my heart to you, which indeed is his, but your father, I fear, will never be won.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Why you would not have him too, Sister, would you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His consent I would, and my fathers, I hope, would easily be wrought. You saw he was willing your other brother should have me at the first sight, merely for his reservedness, and Mihil methought carried himself as civil today as he; I mean, as civilly for a Gentleman, that should not look like one fathers of the Dutch Church at five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: He was put to it today. The noise of the Tavern had almost wrought his zeal into fury, it is scarce out of my head yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you were about to tell me how he first fell into this vein, this vanity indeed.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I will tell you now, and in that something worth your observation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will observe you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My father has an humour, not to like anything at first, nor accept best courtesies of friends,
though presently he finds them most commodious to him, things that he knows not how to be without, and oftentimes desires with the same breath the things he vilified, and scorned them the last syllable he spake before. You saw when your father offered him the use of his house here, till his own be furnished, he cried, hah! are all the houses in the Town yours Sir; and yet presently entreated for it, and thanked him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That shows the best nature, they say.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But that is seldom attended by the best fortune. Nay, in us, I mean, his children, he will like nothing, no, not those actions which he himself cannot deny are virtuous; he will cross us in all we do, as if there were no other way to show his power over our obedience.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It is a strange fatherly care.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now, note the punishment that follows it. There is not a child he has, though we all know what we do, that makes any conscience of crossing him, we have so much of his good nature in us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And that is as odd a duty in children.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I must confess it is a stubbornness. Yet for the most part we do nothing, but that which most Parents would allow in their children: and now for my brother Gabriel, with whom I must bring in the story of another Kinswoman of ours, my father had at home with us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Nay, mark, I pray you, as I would entreat an Auditory, if I now were a Poet to mark the Plot, and several points of my play, that they might not say when it is done, they understood not this or that, or how such a part came in or went out, because they did not observe the passages.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well on, I pray.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My brother Gabriel, when he was a boy, nay,
till within these two years, was the wildest untamed thing that the country could possibly hold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So he is still for aught I know, for I think no man of his Religion i in his wits.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mean in outward conversation, he was the Ringleader of all the youthful Fry, to Fairs, to Wakes, to May-games, football matches, anything that had but noise and tumult in it; then he was Captain of the young train band, and exercised the youth of twenty parishes in martial discipline. O he did love to imitate a soldier the best, --- and so in everything, that there was not an handsome maid in an whole County could be quiet for him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He may be good at that sport still, for there is almost none of his sect holds any other game lawful.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet did he bear the civilest and the best ordered affection to our Kinswoman I spake of.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, I remember.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: So loving to her person, so tender of her honour that nothing but too near affinity of blood could have kept them asunder.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And she did love him as well!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: O dearly, virtuously well; but my father fearing what youth in heat of blood might do, removes my brother Gabriel from home into the service of a Reverend Bishop to follow good examples.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But he learned not to be a Puritan there I hope.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
You shall hear, Sister, soon after came a Gallant into the country from London here, and as we after found, a Citizens son, though he showed like a Lord there. Briefly, he grew acquainted with my brother Mihil. Then wooed and won my
Cousin so secretly, my father never suspected, nor he nor I ever knew whose son he was, nor of what occupation my old lord his father was; but he promised her marriage, clapped her, you may guess where, and so like the slippery Trojan left her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O devilish Rascal!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And foolish creature, she who soon repented it, and with her shame is fled to what part of the world we know not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In truth it is pitiful, that villain would be hanged.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now upon this, my poor brother that loved her so, fell into discontent, forsook his lord, and would have left the Land, but that he was prevented and brought home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And ever since he has been thus religious.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Thus obstinate, for I think verily he does it but to cross my father, for sending him out of the way when the mischief was done.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will not then believe it is Religion in any of the gang of them, but mere wilful affectation. But why, or wherein do you or Mihil cross your father.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I tell you Sister we must. He is so cross himself, that we shall never get anything of him that we desire, but by desiring the contrary.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why then do you desire him to get you an husband?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Because he should get me none. O Sister, both he and Master. Cockbrayne, can wish now that I had had his son.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There is another youth now gone on loves pilgrimage, ever since your father crossed him in your love not to be heard of.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Hush! the old men.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: In good truth sir, I am taken with your conversation. I like it now exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I am glad it pleases you.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: It is very fair and friendly, I find we shall accord.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I am glad I have it for you Sir, I pray, make bold with it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Then pray sir, let me urge my motion a little further to you.

sp.speaker: Cros,
sp.p: What is it? you cannot utter it so easily as I shall grant it, out with it man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That you will be pleased to accept my daughter for either of your sons, your youngest if you please, now I have seen him, I will give him with her presently, either in hand a thousand pound, and five hundred pound a child as fast as he can get them. And all I shall die seized of.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What a Dogbolt is this to think that I should get a child for him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope you do think well on it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray love he does. I hope so too.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mark his Answer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I could find in my heart to ask his good-will myself.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And that were a sure way to go without it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: How say you, sir, is it a match?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I will not stay a minute in thy house, though I lie in the street for it. Housewife, I will sort you with fitter companions, Come, follow me quickly.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Heaven bless me and my child too from matching with such a disposition.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Truly, sir, I longed to be out of the house before.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Before you came in it did you not? ha!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: These new walls do so stink of the lime methinks.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Marry faugh, Goody Foist.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: There can be no healthy dwelling in them this twelve-month yet.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Are you so tender bodied?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Even please yourselves then where yon can like better, and you shall please me.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why you will not thrust me out of your house, will you? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: There is no such haste, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Indeed there is not, nor will I out for all your haste neither I will have look to my bargain.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: With all my heart, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But no more of your idle motions, if you love your ease in your house, your inn here.
Here is a letter, sir, from Master. Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Is the Bearer paid, or give him that if it please you.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Somebody has angered him, and I must suffer.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I sent you to seek my sons, good sir, have you found them? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I cannot find them sir. They went out of the Tavern together, they say, and I have been at Master. Mihils chamber, and there they are not. I went to the Tavern again, and there they were not. Then I beat all the rest of the bushes, in this forest of fools and mad men, and cannot find them I, where ever they be.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Sirrah, go find them me where ever they be, any where, or no where, find them, and find them
quickly; I will find them in your Coxcomb else, do ye see! and bring my sons Sanctity home before it be dark, lest he take up his lodging in a Church porch; and charge Master. Mihil that he come not to me till I send for him. Here is danger in the house. There was a match motion indeed.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good sir, either like my house well, or be pleased to please yourself with some better.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Pray Sir, be quiet in your house, lest I send you out of it to seek another. Let me see my chamber.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: He must have his way, I see.

div2.stage:
Act. IV.
Scoen. I. Enter Bettie, Frank, with swords drawn make fast the doors.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Nay, you perpetual Puss, I will fetch him out of the very bowels of thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He never came so deep himself yet with all that he could do, and I scorn the threatening of a She Marmoset.

sp.speaker: Nick. (Within)
sp.p: why Bettie, Frank, you mankind Carrions you. I vow, open the door, will you both kill one another, and cozen the Hangman of his fees?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Thou hadst been better have bit off the dugs of thy Dam, thou pin buttock Jade thou, than have snapped a bit of mine from me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Here is that shall stay your stomach better than the bit you snarl for. Thou greedy Brach thou.

sp.speaker: Nick. (Within)
sp.p: why wenches, are ye wild? break open the doors.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: That I could split that devilish tongue of thine!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have as good a spite at as ill a member about thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hold, what is the devil in ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Are ye so sharp set ye Amazonian Trulls?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Let me but make one paste at her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray let me go, and let her come.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can no blunter tools than these serve to take down your furies?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Let me come but within nails reach of her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me but try the strength of my teeth upon her.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p:
As Hector betwixt the hosts of Greece and Troy, When Paris and the Spartan King should end Their nine years wars, held up his brazen lance. In signal, that both Armies should surcease, And hear him speak. So let me crave your audience. Dear Bettie be advised, and Frank, forbear Thy thirst of Sisters blood. Whilst I rip up The folly of your strife. Your cases both Have been laid open to me. You contend For love of a lewd Citizen, that sleights, Nay more, disdains, nay more, defies you both. Tony can tell, Mun Clotpoll also knows The words he spake, that you were both poor whores, Not poor alone, but foul infectious harlots. And that he wears your mark with pain and sorrow, Hopeless to claw them off. With constant purpose Never to see you more, unless to greet
Your bumping buttocks with revengeful feet.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Did he say so?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And must we two fall out for such a slanderous Villain?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, agree, agree.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Buss and be friends. Buss, or I will baste ye both, I vow.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Come Sister we will be in for ever now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For my part, Sister, sure I was not out with you.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But did he say he would kick us?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lo here, the man that dares it not deny.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: But do ye hear, Gentlemen. I hope you will use me kindlier then so.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Than how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Than to win all my money, and leave me at stake for the reckoning. Pray do you pay the Drawer for me, though I pay it you again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is it Drawer?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The Gentlewomen and he had 14. shillings. in before you came.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: It is a plain case, your cloak must answer it at the bar, Sir. Drawer, away with it.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Nay, but Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do but look after it, till we be gone, and these shall claw thine eyes out.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well sir, I hope this quarter will not be always lawless.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do you grumble? Master. Cussless.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow you shall have cusses.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes, that you shall.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Cuts and slashes too before we part, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You will not murder me, will you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Damsels forbear; and you, forbear your noise. I vow, I will slit your whistle else? You shall give him due correction civilly, and we will make him take it civilly. Sit you down Sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What will you do with me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, mum.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O, are ye here! was it a brotherly trick do ye think, to leave me to pay one reckoning twice? or did I think never to be made a mouth more, after I had paid my swearing dinner, and am I now a greater mouth than ever I was?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Mum, hold your tongue still in your mouth, lest I halifax it with your teeth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Halifax my tongue. And listen to a business.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Do yon know this man?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, the City mouth we had the other night.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: These are the Sisters that his lavish tongue so lewdly did deprave.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I cry them heartily mercy. Are you of the sweet Sisterhood? I hope to know you all, all the pretty Mumpers in the berry here, before I have done. It is true, I protest, he spake words of you, that such flesh and blood could not bear. He could not have spoken worse of mutton of a groat a quarter.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: And were we so fond to fight for him?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But now we will both be revenged upon the flesh of him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, they shall beat you first. And mark me well. Do thou but stir an hand or foot, or raise a voice that may be heard to the next room, we will cut thy weasand. Now wenches take your course.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Nay, you slave, we will mark you for a Sheep-biter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We will teach you how to scandalise.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Have I given you that you cannot claw off, you Mongrel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Rare, I protest.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There, there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: we will claw thine ears off rather.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O brave.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O outrage, most insufferable, all this goes into my black book.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To him Bettie, at him Frank; there whores, there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fie, fie, forbear, enough, too much in conscience.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: That young man has some pity yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I swear you shall no more.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Alas, good Gentlemen, it is enough.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do you prate? you shall have as much. Come, take the Chair, Sir, the breeches shall bait him too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, they shall. To him and claw him, I will clapperclaw your sides else

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O me! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Heyday! his beard comes off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And his head too. What rotten scab is this?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest, they have pulled my pieced brother in pieces here.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, some disguised villain, and but for doing the State so good service, we would hang him presently without examination.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know him. And you shall not touch him. Best is, he knows nor me. Good Heaven, what Brain-trick has possessed him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, what canst thou be?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, it is an honest fellow, that is only ashamed to run so base a course for his living in his own face. Poor man, I warrant his fear threatens his breeches shrewdly. But let us away, and quickly, our stay is dangerous. Come, we forgot Mich. Croswil and the wenches.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come all away then, Sirrah, thank this Gentleman, and pray for him at the end of your Songs hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Farewell, friend Piece. I will know you better now, before you have it again.

div2.stage: Ex. omnes but Cock. and Cit.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What monsters in mankind? what hell-hounds are they? only as Ovid feigned among the Getes. A friend at need, I with a friend was blessed, Whom I may gratify, and plague the rest. How is it with you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O, I am very sore.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Indeed you are sorely handled. This may warn you out of such caterwauling company. You look like one more civil. And in hope you will be so, I will bring you to a Barber.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Alas, my Cloak.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I will help you to that too, so you with me, Will in an honest plot Assistant be.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O Sir, in anything, and thank you too, Sir.

div2.stage: Scoen. 2. Enter Mihil, Gabriel, Boy, Wine, etcetera .

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A Paris ill ya ben veni. Here is no bush at this door, but good wine rides post upon it, I mean, the signpost. Boy, get you down, and if Nick Rooksbill, or any of his company ask for me, bring them up, do ye hear.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will, I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are welcome to Paris brother Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is nevertheless a Tavern, brother Mihil, and you promised and covenanted with me at the last house of noise and noisomeness, that you would not lead me to any more Taverns.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Lead you brother? men use to be led from Taverns sometimes. You saw I did not lead you nor bring you to any that was more a Tavern than the last, nor so much neither; for here is no Bush you saw.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It was that betrayed and entrapped me: but let us yet forsake it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray let us drink first brother. By your leave here is to you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: One glassful more is the most that I can bear. My head is very full, and laboureth with that I have had already.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There Sir, I will undertake one good fellow, that has but just as much religion as will serve an honest man's turn, will bear more wine than ten of these giddy-brained Puritans, their heads are so full of whimsies.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is mighty heady, mighty heady, and truly I cannot but think that the over much abuse of these outlandish liquors, have bred so many errors in the Romish Church.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Indeed brother, there is too much abuse made of such good creatures. Wine in itself is good, you will grant, though the excess be nought; and Taverns are not contemptible, so the company be good.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is most true, we find that holy men have gone to Taverns, and made good use of them upon their Peregrinations.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
And cannot men be content to take now and
then a cup, and discourse of good things by the way. As thus. Brother, here is a remembrance (if she be living, and have not lost her honour) to our Cousin Dorcas.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O that kinswoman of ours. She was the dearest loss that ever fell from our house.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Pledge her, good brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I do ---

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope it will maudlenize him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: But have you never seen that miscreant that wronged her, since he did that same, they say you knew him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Alas, suppose I had, what could be done? she is lost we see. What good could she receive by any course against him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It had been good to have humbled him, though into the knowledge of his Transgression. And of himself for his souls good, either by course of Law, or else in case of necessity, where the Law promiseth no relief, by your own right hand you might have smote him, smote him with great force, yea, smote him unto the earth, until he had prayed that the evil might be taken from him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This is their way of loving enemies, to bear them into goodness. Well, brother, I may meet with him again, and then I know what to do. If he knew him as I do now, what a religious combat were here like to be at Nicks coming.
Sir, here is a Gentlewoman asks for Master. Rooksbill.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The travelled Gallant, is it not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir, and the old black party, her Landlady with her. But they ask for nobody but him, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say he is here by all means, and bring them up.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Women! pray brother let us avoid the place, let us fly it. What should we do with women in a Tavern?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: No harm assure yourself, cannot we govern ourselves?

div2.stage: Enter Dorcas and Madge, and start back.

sp.p: Nay, Lady, stay, he will be here presently, that you look for.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will not glance an eye toward temptation.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I am amazed sure, I have seen this face, however your habit and the course of time may give it another seeming.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Good Angels, help my thoughts and memory. It is my Kinsman Mihil. What is the other that hides his face, so?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Do you turn away?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: It is my Cousin Gabriel, strangely altered.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Come hither you. I will make a little bold with you. Thou that hast been a concealer of more sins in women's actions, than thou hast grizzled hairs.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sure I will speak to him, he always loved me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Reveal a truth to me on my demand, now instantly, without premeditation. I will cut thy tongue out else.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What is here to do? do you think I am a devil? that you make such conjurations over me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I think thou art as true a servant of his as any Bawd can be. But lie now if thou darest. How long have you known that Gentlewoman? and what do you know by her?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Here is a stir about nothing. I know nothing by her, not I. Nor whether she has anything or nothing, that a woman should have by the report of knowledge of man, woman or beast, not I. She came to me but this morning, with a purpose to set me up in my new house as I hoped. But she has taken a course to make it honestly spoken of already, to my utter undoing, but she never comes within my doors again, as I hope to thrive by my Trade hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Pray look upon me, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Was she so resolutely bent, and so soon altered?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Upon the very first sight of the very first man that came into my house, the very first hour of my setting up in it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What man was that?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A shame take him, your roaring friend, Nick. I think she is enamoured of him, or of something she guesses he has; and would fain play the honest woman with him, that never played honest man with woman in his life.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: It is she, and it is most wonderful.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: If you knew who I were, you would not be so strange to me.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And here she comes me a hunting after him, like a fondling, whilst half a dozen pieces might have been gotten at home by this time, and she have had the halves of it in her purse by this time; if she would have done, as I thought, she would have done by this time.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Alas, poor Owlet.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I sent whooping after the best guest that haunt my house, to have taken the first fruits of her conversation, and she would not see a man of them, to my undoing.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well leave thy hooting, Madge, and hold thy peace. thou shalt get by it.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Yes, I shall get a good name shortly, and this gear hold, and turn beggar, I shall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray sir, but one word.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Speak to her, brother, it is our Cousin Dorcas.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Will you abuse me too? is she not lost?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And will not you give her leave to be found again? his wine and her sudden apprehension works on him at once. Cousin, I will speak to you, though I confess the miracle of our meeting thus amazes me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O Cousins both. As ye are Gentlemen, and of that noble stock, whose mere remembrance, when he was given up, and at the brink of desperate folly, stroke that reverend fear into my soul, that hath preserved my honour from further falling. Lend me now your aid, to vindicate that honour by that man, that threw me in the way of loss and ruin.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All shall be well, good Cousin, you shall have both hands and hearts to re-estate you in him. So that in fact you have not wronged that honour, since he forsook you.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: On my soul I have not.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Infants then shall be pardoned. Brother speak.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You were wont still to be my lovingest Cousin.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What a strange dream has wine wrought in my head.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I hope it will work out his superfluous zeal. And render him civil Christian again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
It is no dream, good Cousin, you are awake, And I, that Dorcas, for whom you have wished Affinity of blood might be dispensed with. And you
to be my choice. So well you loved me.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And will above my life affect you still. But you must leave these gauds and profane dressings.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Bawds did he say? how comes he to know me trow?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: How came my Cousin Gabriel thus translated. Out of gay clothes, long hair, and lofty spirit, Stout and brave action, manly carriage; into so strict a Reformation? Where is the martial humour he was wont so to affect.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: His purity and your disgrace fell on you both about a time, Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do you swear by your FAITH?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He is falling back again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Some more wine. You will drink with our Cousin, brother, will you not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What wine is it, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, in a cup of sincere love.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What other wine you please, Gentlemen, we have none such in the house.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Of the same we had, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Call not for wine for us, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Assuredly, we are no profane wine bibbers, not we.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Modest, and well spoken verily, she should be a Sister or a Matron.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we will all drink for the good of the house. It is upon putting down, they say, and more of the neighbours. But Cousin, he knew you not today.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, nor dreams of me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And the old one knows nothing, does she.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: No, by no means.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: She can bewray nothing then. My brother knows not him. I only do for his fair Sisters sake, of which you may hear more hereafter; in the mean, bear yourself fair and free, as if you knew him not, and I will work him to your end, never fear it.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You are a noble Spokesman.

div2.stage: [Bawd and Gabriel confer devoutly the while.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Truly, you speak most edifyingly.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well said, give it to my brother. Drink to our Cousin, Brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will, and to that virtuous Matron, whose care of her, I hope, tends unto good edification. --- Truly the wine is good, and I was something thirsty.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Best drink again then, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will follow your motherly advice.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: It will work, anon, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And you have travelled Cousin. I may suppose you brought this well disposed Gentlewoman from Amsterdam with you. And this unto your welcome, hoping I shall be informed by you how the two zealous brethren thrive there? that broke in Saint. Hellens.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Of that or anything sir, pray drink again, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You Jade you, hold your tongue.

div2.stage: Enter Nick, Anthony, Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, are ye here Gallants! I made all the haste I could, but was stayed, I vow, by the bravest sport, baiting of a fellow or two with our Puss-cats here. I could even find in my heart to marry them both for their valours.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Those words are daggers.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I pray dissemble your passion.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What? are you acquainted already?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee she was a brave Madonna?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: How long have you had acquaintance with her, Nick?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Never saw her before this morning, Aye, standing upon her Balcony.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly Cousin, I think it was you that I saw today too, standing upon a Balcony.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You spell very modestly, sir. Your brother, I take it. But did you call her Cousin, sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes sir, she is my Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: It will out too soon. Why Nick, thou knowest these kind of creatures call and are called Cousins commonly.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, in their tribe. But I thought he had been too holy for them. But Dammy ---

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O fearfully profane!

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You said you had a story to relate, of dire misfortune, and of unquoth hearing. I come to hear your story, what stop you your ears at? sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I dare not speak it but in thy reproof. Thou swearest Gee o Dee, Dee am thee, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thou liest, I called her Dammy, because her name is Damyris,

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I say thou liest, her name is Dorcas, which was the name of an holy woman.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Shall we have things and things? I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I protest.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This will spoil all. Brother, I pray forbear.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I may not forbear, I am moved for to smite him; yea, with often stripes to smite him; my zealous wrath is kindled, and he shall fly before me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Let me entreat you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bet., Frank.
sp.p: What fury is this?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Great Damboys shrink, and give a little ground.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will pursue him in mine indignation.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O me!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And beat him into Potsherds.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Now he has banged the Pitcher, he may do anything.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray, brother, be persuaded.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A brother to be so controlled?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You sir, put up your Steel stick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I desire but to know first, if he be a brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes marry is he, sir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Sir, I am satisfied. So let him live.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to ask you, do these men take part with the brethren?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and are brothers a little disguised, but for some ends.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Some State occasions.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Mere Intelligencers, to collect up such and such observations, for a great Separatist that is now writing a book against playing at Barley-break, moulding of Cockle-bread, and such like profane exercises.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly such exercises are profane exercises, that bear the denomination of good things ordained for man's use, as Barley, Cockles, and Bread are such things to be made sports and play games? I pray you let me see these brethren again, to make my atonement with them. And are those Sisters too, that were with them?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
O, most notorious ones, and are as equally disguised to be as rank Spies as the other. 'slid man, and they should be taken for such as they are, they would be cut off presently. They came in this
mad humour to be merry with you for my sake.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray let them come again, I shall not be well until I have rendered satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You must do as they do then, or they will think you are a Spy upon them.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will be as merry as they, let wine be given unto us.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: More wine, Boy, and bid them all come in.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas, Cousin, let him drink no more.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Cousin, it shall be for his good and yours, as I will order it.

div2.stage: Enter Nick. Anthonie. Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank, Drawer with wine.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All welcome, not any repetition, but begin anew.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will begin it, two glasses: it shall be a faithful Salutation to all the Brothers and Sisters of ---

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The Blade and the Scabbard.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: It shall go round.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will swear you do not well to let him drink so.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well said civil Roarer.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Let it go round, go to, you are a wag. I know what you mean by the Blade and the Scabbard.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Who could have thought this had been such a brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Nay, who could have thought you had been of the brethren.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brethren sir, we are the Brothers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yea, the disguised ones.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: How? disguised ones?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Do not cross him again. If thou dost, and I do not maul thee. Yes, brother, these are virtuous
men however they seem.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I have so much virtue as to rebuke thee for lying. But we are brethren, sir, and as factious as you, though we differ in the Grounds; for you, sir, defy Orders, and so do we; you of the Church, we of the Civil Magistrate, many of us speak in the nose, as you do; you out of humility of spirit, we by the wantonness of the flesh; now in devotion we go beyond you, for you will not kneel to a ghostly father, and we do to a carnal Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I will stop your mouth, you said you came to be merry.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, and brought Fiddlers along, but they must play in the next room, for here is one breaks all the Fiddles that come in his reach. Come sir, will you drink, dance, and do as we do?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will drink, I will dance, I will kiss, or do anything, any living thing with any of you that is Brother or Sister. Sweetheart let me feel thy Cony.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I now he sin. Play Fiddlers. Dance. All bravely performed, admirably well done, etcetera .

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, thou art a brother after my own heart.

sp.speaker: Women.
sp.p: We cannot commend you enough, sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: This done in civil sort among ourselves, I hope, will prove no scandal to a brother.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: It will prove an honour to our faction.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I thirst to do it honour.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Give him some wine, he thirsts.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Thou little dapper thing, thou, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou seest he can scarce stand.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
No, my religious brethren, no more wine. Enough is a feast, and little doth suffice. I thirst to do some honour to our cause. To lead
forth legions to fight a battle against our malignant adversaries.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brave.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such an employment now would make me famous, for my sufficiency of Art in Arms.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, this man has hidden things in him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He has as brave a warlike spirit, man, before his precise humour tainted it, as ever breathed in Hector.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow then, a good orderly diet of nothing but sack for a week together, would revive it in him, and bring it to good again.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I hope, it is done already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How do you, sit?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I fear some Jesuitical fumes have invaded my Brain pan. All methinks goes whirly, whirly, whirly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Best lie down upon a bed. Drawer!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Soldiers must not be curious. A Bench or anything.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The Gentleman may have a bed here, if it please you. But sir, there is an old angry Gentleman below, that asks for you, and by all description for that mortified Gentleman. And will by all means press into your room here.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: It is my father.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O me! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mad., Bet., Fran.
sp.p: We shall be all clapped up.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Fear nothing, veil your face a little; Who is with him?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Nobody but his old Serving-man, that it seems discovered you. You may put this Gentleman into this inner room, and keep the Key yourself. I know not what charge he has about him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Admirable honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: And you may tell your father he is gone, for he is gone you see.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow. a wit.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Now if you will be civil, I may bring him up to you, if not, because he is your father, we will thrust him out of doors, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Notable rascal, well sir, let him up. I know how to fit him.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: But this delays my business, Cousin, and will, I fear, frustrate my hopes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor hinder anything, I will warrant thee, he is thine. Play Fiddlers, the other dance.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Will you! protest.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are not wild?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Come Wenches, if he venture in his fathers sight, shame take us and we blush.

sp.speaker: Cross., Belt.
sp.p: And I had not sold all my land to live upon my money in Town here, out of danger or the Statute, I would give thee a Copihold for this discovery.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank your worship, and truly it is a goodly sight, methinks if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I am glad it likes you. Heigh, excellent good again. Heigh, Heigh, what an happiness may fathers boast, that can bring their children up to this.
I cry ye mercy, Gentlemen all. Ha! I am sorry I interrupted your serious private occasions.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Would you speak with any here, sir?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It is my father, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Thy father? hold thy peace; darest thou use thy father thus? to spend thy time thus! ha! Is this place fit for the son of a Gentleman of quality? ha! why dost not answer me, does this company sort with thy reputation? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir, the company. ---

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, I say, or are these exercises allowable for a Gentleman, that ever said or heard Grace at his fathers Table? answer me that.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: If it please you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Hold thy peace when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The company, sir, offends not you, I hope, you see the worst of us.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: In good time, sir, you are the distracted Gentlemen, I take it, that asked him if he would moot tonight? Is this your mooting? do you put cases to your Wenches, or they to you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thy father talks too much.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Which are the better Lawyers? ha!

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But that you are his father, sir, and an old man, and he an honest young Gentleman, and our friend, we would tell you.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I thank you for him, yes truly, heartily; and for your good opinion of him, heartily. Pray keep him amongst you while ye have him, for I will have no more to say to him, I. Is your Invectives against drinking, wenching, and the abomination of the times come to this? is this your spending of time more precious than money? is it you that knows not what to do with money but to buy books; and were drawn with such unwillingness to a Tavern? ha! you shall graze upon Littletons Commons, or eat nothing but books, if it please you, for any exhibition thou ever gettest from me --- And in that faith thou hast lost a father. Come sir, you have brought me to a goodly sight here; would any Villain but thyself have showed his Master light to see so much woe! Thy Coxcomb shall yet pay for it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O sir, O.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: This was your trim sight, was it?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: But well remembered. Pray where is your brother? my son I would say; for I know no brother or father thou hast. Where is Gabriel?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He is not here, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Did you not tell me, Sirrah, he was here?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I told you then too much. I feel it here.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: He was here, sir, but he is gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: So, so, he is lost. He must be cried, or we shall never find him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I will warrant you, I will find him yet tonight, sir. Pray Gentlemen pay you the Reckoning, I will wait upon my father home.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Was that spoke like a son of mine? must others pay your reckoning, and I in place; take that, and do not make me mad. And why should you home with me? I pray, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Because sir, it grows dark, and it is the worst way as it is about the town; so many odd holes a man may slip into; pray take me with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Pray take no care for me, sir, and let the way be as it is. Do not think me worse at it in the dark than yourself, I beseech you. But you talked of the Reckoning, pray let not the want of money for that hinder the search of your brother. There is towards your pains for that; and so for a farewell to you and your friends here, till I hear thou keepest better company, let me hear no more of thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: There was no way to get this money, and be rid of him, but to offer him my service He would have driven me out before him else. But come, let us see my brother that went to sleep in so warlike a Passion. I hope he will wake in a better.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Mun Clotpoll, thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: No, I protest, but struck with admiration at the old Blades humour.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come, Dammy and the rest, be merry. I vow, we will sup together, and so at last hear all thy dismal story.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I mean he shall, and such an Audit make, As shall restore her honour from the stake.

div2.stage:
Act V.
Scaen. I. Enter Crossewill Solus.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p:
What has this Coxcomb Cockbrayne writ me here? That he desires his absence be excused. What have I to do with him? when I send for him, let him come to me. That he is upon a point of discovery in a most excellent project for the weeding of this Garden? what Garden? what project? A project he says here for the good of the Republic, Repudding. This fellow has in instead of brains, a Cobweb in his Noddle, with little straws, feathers, and wings of dead Butterflies hanging in it, that having motion by his airy fancy, there dance and keep a Racket; it is to teach women silence, or some such foolish impossibility. He is ambitious to be called into authority by notice taken of some special service he is able to do the State aforehand. But what great service he is able to do it, or which way to undertake it, falls not in the reach of my imagination. But good Master Croswill, by your favour now, what reason have you to slight or wrangle at this man? this honest Cockbrayne? that has always been a constant friend to you, and officious in many good ways, and is a Gentleman, not only of good descent and estate, but of a good disposition. And you two, Master. Crossewill, by your leave, have always agreed like
neighbours children. Aye, the devil was in it, and now he vexes me again; we agreed in one point so well, that we have undone a couple of our children by it, and hindered the getting of I know not how many more. His son and my daughter should have married. And on a sudden he and I both consented to a dislike of the match and broke it, and have both repented it an hundred times since. We agree very well in that point; and now is his son irrecoverably lost, and my daughter resolutely bent to be an Ape leader in Limbo. But what is all this to the affliction I suffer in my sons now? that one of them from a riotous boy, should grow into a Puritanical Woodcock; and the the other from a civil well qualified fellow, turned absolute Ruffian. There, there, Aye there is the devil in it. I could beat myself for getting such children.
See, see, my Master for want of other company fallen out with himself, if it please you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It does not please me, nor thou pleasest me, nor anything pleases me. The world is bent to cross me, and thou shalt feel it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O good sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Is it not so, sir, was not that dunce Gabriel, a most notorious wild thing Before he steered a Religious course? but then he run so full a sail, that he passed and was beyond the line of Religion before he was aware; and as he passed it under the torrid Zone of Zeal, the Calenture took him on the pate, that he is mad with it, and as far beyond Religion now as it is to it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Sir, there is hope that he may be fetched half way back again, by your fatherly advisement, and become a sound man.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: And then was not Mihil so civil, that he made me even sick to see him. And now is he flown out as far into riot the other way.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: But he, sir, will appear a present comfort to you, he is reclaimed already; you shall never see such a Reformation in a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What is this you tell me? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: He has cast off his long-curled hair and all.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: He had been better have cut his head off. Where is he!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Below sir, and a Gentlewoman with him, but very much afraid to appear to you. I never saw a man so timorsome.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Do you think it fit I should go down to him, or he come up to me, sir, ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I will fetch him, here is a life!

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I charged he should not come at this house too, for fear he might be catched with this mechanic fellows daughter, though her portion be a round one. And let him take heed he look not at her.
Bless me! what changeling is this? he is in his Brothers cut.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir, --- Sir. ---

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Would you speak with any here, sir, do you know me. I know not you, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The sense of your late displeasure, sir, has so humbled me into the knowledge of myself, that on the wings of true obedience, I flew after you to make a childes submission at your feet, to crave your pardon for my riotous transgression, and to ask your blessing.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
A delicate speech, pray take it for fashion sake.
But if I know how to look towards thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray sir, bestow it really upon me.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: God bless thee, I say, and so much many honest men bestow daily on sons that are none of their own, if thou beest mine, how camest thou thus like a fellow that had narrowly scaped the Pillory, and bragged in the publication of his ears? not an hair left to hide them.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: To show my readiness to reform my life, sir. And yet a willingness withal to live, as well, as civilly, in which I am in all humility to prefer a suit to you. You know, sir, I am but a younger brother.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What will this come to?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Here is a widow, sir, a Gentlewoman of great estate, and of a well known life. Ancient she is, and has had husbands. How many?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Four truly, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Four sir, I would not lie. Of which the worst spoke well of her on his deathbed.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What is that to me or thee? come to the point.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I have all wooed and won her, sir, and crave but your good-will to marry her. I have brought a Churchman and a Kinsman to give her.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Why so, what needs two words then? do you think I can deny you?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: If he does grant it, it is the first request that ever he granted in his life. Sure the old Matchmaker the devil thinks I am in earnest to marry this beast. And puts a readiness in his hand to forward it.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Widow, you are welcome. Why call you not your Priest? or tarry sir, let me question you but a little, Do you think seriously you love this widow?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Better than many men love their wives, I am persuaded.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: It is very well, what children have you widow?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Never had any, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Very well still.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor ever like to have any, sir, that is the comfort. We shall live at the less charge.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Thou art a covetous and a preposterous Knave. Wouldst thou bury up thy youth in barren ground? dost seek after wealth, and not after issue? dost love to feed on other men's leavings? or travel only in a beaten path? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A man goes certainest on his journey so, sir, and less trouble it is you know to go in at a great gate, than a narrow wicket.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: You have said enough, sir, and delight to cross me; but I will cross you for once, and lay a cross upon you, shall perhaps carry you to your grave. Go, fetch your Priest.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I will face it as far as I dare. I hope I shall have the grace to pull my hand from the book when it comes so far.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Widow, you are resolved to have him too.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Before all men in the world by your fair leave, Aye.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: You shall not have him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Without your free consent, I will not.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I am resolved I will do it. And it will be the best cross trick that ever I did in my life. Pray let me speak in some more private with yon.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: If I but escape Bridewell, I care not.

div2.stage: Scoen. 2. Enter Mihil, Anthonie, Katharine, Parson.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Now Tonie, she is thine own. Now Sister Kate,
he is thine. The Priest has pronounced it. I say, Amen to it. And heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now you have done the best brotherly office that ever made a Sister happy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And the friendliest to a friend. We have been casting for it, Sweet, this Twelve-month, and Heaven pardon me. I vowed never to take acquaintance of my Father, till it were effected. Although I know of late he has been willing.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And so is mine, I know, but yet he swore, that I should match myself before he knew it, or I should never marry.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You will find him of another mind towards me, and force me into wedlock presently.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: You have ta'en the likeliest, course that could be. But what is your disguised woman, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What you shall never know, Sister, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Come sir, I have broken off the match with your widow; and she is content to leave you as she found you. And now take me this pretty, simpering, plump lipped, ruddy cheeked, white necked, long-fingered Virgin in hand, or I will swindge you, Sirrah, look to it. If you cannot live civilly with a young wife, you cannot but be mad with an old, I think. Besides, she is a friends daughter of mine, and prepared by her discreet father here to love you. Come, and kiss her, quickly, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I cannot do it for all the wealth in the world.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Kiss a Maid I never saw above twice in my life.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: He will have me think him a bastard, do I what I can. Canst thou see a Maid twice, and not kiss her?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, twenty times, sir, and not kiss her, or if once, not above, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: But you shall kiss her above and below, sir, and in every room of the house, sir, before you part. Stand fair pretty one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know not how to do it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You were not best let me instruct you. I can be angry too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His back side is towards me.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Turn yourself, Sirrah, or I will turn you. Go to, bend your body a little and be hanged. So, now come your way, and say after your little Sir John here, I Mihil take thee, Lucie, etcetera . As learning shall enable him to proceed without book.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Pray let them do it in the next chamber, they are too bashful afore us. There are witnesses enough. Go all in, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Widow, will you give me leave to obey my father?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: With all my heart, and say Amen to the marriage.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I think I shall have my will at last upon one of my rebellious offspring.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And now, pray give me leave sir, to let you know how happy I do hold myself in this marriage. I did like this Son better than the other before. And now I like him better than I did at my former view of him, by some Reformation that I do observe in him. And I do not a little rejoice in the honour I may have to call you brother.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p:
That very word brother out of his mouth, has turned my stomach. I must pull all in pieces again. And yet let me see these young bloods when they
are set on it; if they do not marry, they will do worse. Let them even go on now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You may easily conceive, sir, what a comfort it will be unto me, that I now growing old, and having (I give praise for it,) wealth enough, and no child that I make account of but this one daughter, may, before I die, see Grandchildren that I may have by her sufficiently provided for, be they more or less in number, they may have enough.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: There he is again, he calls my Grandchildren that shall be, his Grandchildren. Am I a Gentleman, and can hear this? if it be not too late, I will spoil the getting of your Grandchildren.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heaven give you joy. Heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: What, are you married?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I do pronounce them man and wife.

sp.speaker: Ant., Mad., Kat.
sp.p: And we are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: What remedy?

sp.speaker: Mih., Luc.
sp.p: We are, and crave your blessings.

sp.speaker: Cross., Rook.
sp.p: All blessings be upon you,

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: But you, sir, Master. Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I will only gratify the Minister.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Do so, and pay him well, it is, perhaps, for the dearest fault that ever thou didst.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
There is for your pains, sir. Madge, there is for you. Enough to purchase thee a Licence to sell Ale, Tobacco, and Strong water again in codpiece row, for here will be no dwelling for thee, I see that. Now, brother Anthonie, go you all back to the company we left, and see that my Instructions be followed
concerning my brother Gabriel, Nick, and his Dammie,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All, all.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Shall he go from me?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, but you shall follow him presently, trust to me Sister. Go, take no leave of them. I will bring them upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Are you at leisure now, sir, to tell me of your brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, to my grief, sir, praying you may have patience.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: To your grief, sir, he is not dead then? Younger brothers seldom grieve for their Elders death.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray bear it as you may, sir. I left him in an heavy plight. And let me speak it with sorrow, he lay speechless.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Alack the day, good Gentleman, my son-in-law, perhaps, is heir already.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: And hast thou been here all this while fooling or wiving (all is a matter) and left thy brother in danger? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He is well attended, sir, and looked unto. Nor would I wish you see his weak estate. It can but grieve you, sir, my wife and sister; together with myself, will go. Or if It please my father Rooksbill here, because his power in this quarter is available.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Go, show the way. I will go in person, I. My son is my son.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Nay, pray sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Yes, cause you have a wife, you shall control me. Will you go on, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well, I will bring you to him, sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What was your widow, sir, she stunk of Aqua-vitae, fearfully.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I will tell thee as we go. Kiss.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What a drunken sot was I, that knew thee not all this while? I vow, thy story pities me. I will marry thee, and turn thee to thy friends, for I am sure I have none that will keep thee for my sake.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: I ask no further satisfaction of you, than to be honested by marriage. I will work for a poor living.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Prithee Mun seek me a Priest.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I have no acquaintance in their function, I.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: My Cousin Mihil said he would bring or send one.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There is no starting, that Mihil has a sist over me. I vow, and thou wert not his Kinswoman, thou should to the Common yet.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Father, how come you hither?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did not the company send for me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, not we.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The City mouth, that pecked us at my lodging last night, came to me with an abominable scratched face, and warned me on a business hither.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I smell some trick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Some treachery upon the brotherhood, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Timorous thing! what in our own Quarter?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If you doubt anything, it is best remove. The fellow was sorely handled.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I would but see the carcass of authority prance in our Quarter, and we not cut his legs off. Welcome Tonie, what hast thou brought the word here to pass for the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, you must make a wedding night of it Nick, Mihil will go no less.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: My Vow is passed, and before you, sir, I confirm it. This is my wife. Anon, you shall perform the holy Ceremony,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is well, pray sir, retire yourself to the next room there a while, and stay you with him, Lady. But what do you with Gabriel? Is it not time to wake him yet?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: It is now upon the point, he has slept two hours.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Father, you will see a brave experiment upon a Gentleman that has been a youth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And of the Philoblathici, as we are now.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And since was grown one of the reformed, and we are now in practice to retrieve, and bring him back to his first condition.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have you followed all Mihils directions?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hitherto we have. First, you saw he was laid defunct in Sack, next in his sleep, we have accoutred him in martial habiliments, and now we mean to wake him with alarms shall affright the silly humour out of him, and render him his warlike faculty, or our Art fails.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where be the Wenches?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The Sisters of the Scabbard, there is the sport of it. They have their parts to play upon him too. But for his drink now when he wakes, you said you would have a bottle of the woman's what do you call it yonder? the Medea.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What? the charmed liquor that Medea brewed to make old father AEson young again? Must that renew his youthful spirit in him?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, Sack will do better. When he wakes he will be very dry, then a quart draught of good Canary will so screw him up. It is time it were now in practice. So, softly, softly. We must but half wake him at first.

div2.stage: A Bed put forth, Gabriel on it, Bettie and Frank.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O some small drink.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Here, drink it off, sir,
Drum and Trumpet. An Alarm.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surprised by the enemy, whilst we have played the Sluggard in our Tents.

sp.speaker: Capt., Nick., Clot.
sp.p: Hold Captain, hold, we are your soldiers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You are Mutineers, and have disturbed my rest. And I will do Martial Justice on you all.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, hold, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Know you not discipline? or are you grown rebellious in the Camp. I will teach you warfare.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You have conjured a fury into him to beat us into fitters.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: My pate bleeds for it, I protest.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will make you know command.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Noble Commander, hold thy furious hand, and hear thy soldiers speak.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What have we women for our Martial Music?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: None but the she trumpet, a neighbour here, and her Sister, that was Drum major to my Country Amazons, that pulled up the Enclosures to lie all in Common.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Is the enemy in the field?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Upon their march, Captain, and we your officers: But roused you up to be in readiness.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
You are my Lieutenant, you my Ancient, and you two my Sergeants; and you must know the Commander
you serve under, to be none of those Letter carriers that know not so much as the terms of discipline, what a Flanker is, Not a Raveling is. Nor a Petard is. Nor a Curtain is. Nor a Bulwark is. Nor a Bastile is. Nor a Counterscarp is. Nor a Case-mate is. A Gabion is: Nor any left word of fortification. How can such freshwater Captains command?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Right noble Colonel. He shall be our Colonel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: One soldier made up of Sack, is worth as many as would drink a fresh water river dry.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I knew, men of abilities should at last be put in action. Valiant men and wise, Are only fit for weighty enterprise.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O noble Colonel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What would an upstart Militaster now, That knew no rudiments of discipline, nor Art of war, do in a sudden service? or say, when I know how to have my Ordnance planted here, my Cavalry mounted here, my Battery discoverer on such a point, my Trenches cut thus, my Mine carried thus, my Gabions raised thus. Here my Parapet, there my Pallisadoe on the top of that. The enemy made saultable six hundred paces there. And I draw out my Musketeers to flank them in their Trenches here, while my Pikes and Targetiers advance to the breach there. What would Captain, my Lords man, or Sergeant major my Ladies Kinsman, sent in by honourable favour, do or say in such an expedition?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Braver and braver still.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: This goes beyond the Blade and the Baton.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
Or how would their brains lie in their breeches, when the able Captain leads up his men in the Head of a Troop bravely, charges with his shot,
makes a stand with his Pikes, does execution with his Sword, the Cannon playing, the Drum beating, the Shot thumping, the Ensigns waving, the Arms clashing, the Air rending, Dust and Smoke clouding, Blood raining. And then to bring up such a Division to fight, make good such a Ground, relieve such a Squadron, fetch off such a loss, reinforce the Ranks that are broken. March on, Come off. Beat the Besogne that lie hid in the Carriages. O the renowned life of a worthy Commander.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sound Drum and Trumpet.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Colonel, a Colonel.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Whither hast thou brought me? does thy brother lie speechless in this house? ha! what in the name of tumult can these be?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray sir, attend, you will be pleased anon.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: A still march now. So, I have lost a great many of my men. But courage yet, you poor remainder of my scattered Troops. Stand. Qui vala. An Ambuscado of the enemy. Alarm. Lieutenant, charge in with your Shot. Now Gentlemen, for the honour of covent garden, make a stand with your Pikes; in to the short sword; well fought, take Prisoners. Sound a Retreat now. Fair, fair in the coming off. So, it was bravely performed.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Must we not fall to rifling now, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Part fair on all sides, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What is this, a vision, sure I do ail something.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Is it possible it is thou? art thou run mad as far as hell the the other way now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My wicked, caitiff, reprobate son is here too. Pray let me flee, I am but a dead man else.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You shall receive no harm, sir. Lay by your Arms my Masters. I bring none but friends.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Thou canst not make that good, my father is there.

sp.speaker: Mih
sp.p: I will make him friends with thee. Go and dispatch within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will see it done, and take our new made Brides with us for witnesses.

sp.speaker: Rook
sp.p: Has his shame yet taught him to shun my sight.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And shall return him instantly your comfort.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Unpossible, unpossible.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Attend the event.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I rather thought I should have found you, sir, disputing with the Pastors, and the Elders; yet to say truth, this is the better madness. What can this mean? how came he thus translated? what Charms, or what Enchantments are upon him?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What Babel was a building in my brains? But now it turns, and I can recollect The knowledge of a father, brother, Sister. And that a thousand vain imaginations, Like scatterings of light things upon the earth, Rushes, loose leaves, sprigs, straws, and dust Contracted by a whirlwind, were blown up, And lodged in the rich Seat of Contemplation, Usurping there the room of virtuous thoughts. Honour awake me from this Lethargy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What can those women that appear like furies be in this action?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They were but used as properties to give new motion to his mortified condition.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
I know not what to say to anything; there
is some Spell upon me too. My anger has forsook me. What are those men that bear a countenance. As if they stood indifferently affected to Bedlam and Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Meaning by us, sir. If our sight offend you, Know we are men that dare forbear the place.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Aye son, let us go, our stay is dangerous.
They look like Peace maintainers, we will fall off.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: O tarry, Gentlemen, we are all undone else. If you make not your peace before you stir, both you and I must suffer.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: The Magistrates and Officers with their Billmen have ta'en us by surprise. They are in the house.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: O me! the blew Gown College.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wheels and whips. I feel what we must go to. Did not I say our stay was dangerous?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Did not I say there was some subtle practice upon the Philoblatici? and that we were betrayed hither?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: There is no escaping forth. And Gentlemen, It will but breed more scandal on my house, and the whole plantation here, if now you make rebellious uproar. Yield your weapons, and welcome Justice but like subjects new, and peace will follow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: But where is Nick? where is Tonie?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They shall yield up their weapons. So do you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes yes, it is best.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Shall we, sir, shall we?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes sir, you shall.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p:
So, sir, I will then, not the Blade alone. But
for your more security, the Baton, There see my Arms forth coming.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say they shall have fair welcome, What are they married?

div2.stage: Enter Nick. Dorcas, Ant. Kat. Luc.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, as fast as troth and holy words can bind them.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: It is well. Now sir, let me entreat your favour. It is my first suit to you since I was your son, That before others entrances distract our troubled Scene, these may be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Even unto the earth, sir, and humbled with as true a penitence, as son can be for wronging of a father, I beg your pardon and blessing.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Give it him, Brother Rooksbill, I dare say it will make him a good man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Heaven make him so. My blessing and my prayers shall not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What? my Niece Dorcas made an honest woman?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Was that the man that wronged my Cousin Dorcas?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and has now made ample recompense.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Here they are altogether, sir.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
Lay hands on all. First, on that old Ruffian, the Incendiary, that sets the youthful bloods on fire here with his Infernal discipline. Next, take his sons, there is one, that young Blade there. Have I now got within ye, Gentlemen? will you have Songs ex tempore? know ye me now? a ha! I will be called the
Weeder of this Garden. Take up those She weeds there. I have the rank one here. I took her straggling in my Round even now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My Tenant, I take it, Mistress. Margerie Owlet.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Your widow sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: But for a shift sir, now you know my aim.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O good your worship, as you came of a woman.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Peace Circes, cease thy charms. What cluster have we here now. O here is another of the sons of noise.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That is my son now, sir, by your leave, and I will bail him.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What Master. Rooksbil, are you here? what woman is this?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: My Niece, sir, his sons wife. And I will bail her.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What Master. Croswill, you among this Ging too? How will you escape commitment?

sp.speaker: Crass.
sp.p: Why, Master. Cockbrayne? how his brains crow now?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Who is here? your daughters too? but what are these?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I hope they will prove my sons, and be indifferent men in time, sir, by that time their hair may grow, or be reduced to an indifferent length.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: That is done on me already, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now he looks as like a Rogue as ever he did again.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And sir, for me, now that my Cousin is restored, and the wild fury of my wine abated. I do you the obedience of a son, acknowledging my former formal habit was more of stubbornness than true devotion. For which I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: There is more deceit under these half Footballs, than in whole Pudding bags. Well boys, be you indifferent sons, neither too hot nor too cold. I have found a fault in myself, I confess. I will reform it, and be an indifferent father.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O here is the man I sought, whom, I confess, I am half sorry to commit with the rest, because I found him civiler.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hoping you will not stake that good opinion, I will now come nearer to you. And since here is such a convention of love and joy. I hope my offering of a sons true duty may find Indulgency.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What? my son Antonie?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: How? how? your son that should have had my daughter? Come hither Kate, now if thou lovest him, take him. Are you content, friend Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O sir, most happily.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why run you not together?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is too late, or needless now for me to marry her.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Is it come to that? and if I do not swindge him --- . Are you too good, sir, for my daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I do not say so, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Housewife, do you like him?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: No more than he does me, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Get you together, or I will swaddle you both into one, you perverse fools.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, the truth is, we are married already.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: It is so, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Heyday! who am I trow? how durst you do it without my consent?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I had your consent, sir, you commanded me to take my choice in whom I pleased, before you would take notice.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I cannot abide this wrangling. Give you joy.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Joy and my blessing on you. Why I know not whom to commit now.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You have done the Commonwealth a special piece of service the while with your State brains. But let us make a night of this, I pray.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sir, the parties have given me satisfaction, and I am content they be released.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: There is an honest fellow now, and looks like one that would be beaten every day for ready money. Go now, while ye are well, and be seen no more in this Precinct.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Never if it please your worships, never.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It was built for no such vermin. Hence away. And may the place be purged so every day. It is no unworthy member may be found, To pester or to vilify this ground. That as it was intended, it may be A Scene for Virtue and Nobility.

sp.speaker: EPILOGUE
sp.p: It is not the Poets Art, nor all that we By life of Action can present of it, ye Can or ought make us to presume a Play Is good, it is you approve it. Which that you may It cannot misbecome us, since our gains Come by your favour, more than all our pains. Thus to submit us unto your commands. And humbly ask the favour at your hands.
It is done. And now that Poets can divine, Observe with what Nobility doth shine Fair covent garden. And as that improves, May we find like Improvement in your Loves.
